19""" 

20A collection of basic statistical functions for Python. The function 

21names appear below. 

22 

23 Some scalar functions defined here are also available in the scipy.special 

24 package where they work on arbitrary sized arrays. 

25 

26Disclaimers: The function list is obviously incomplete and, worse, the 

27functions are not optimized. All functions have been tested (some more 

28so than others), but they are far from bulletproof. Thus, as with any 

29free software, no warranty or guarantee is expressed or implied. :-) A 

30few extra functions that don't appear in the list below can be found by 

31interested treasure-hunters. These functions don't necessarily have 

32both list and array versions but were deemed useful. 

33 

34Central Tendency 

35---------------- 

36.. autosummary:: 

37 :toctree: generated/ 

38 

39 gmean 

40 hmean 

41 mode 

42

44------- 

45.. autosummary:: 

46 :toctree: generated/ 

47 

48 moment 

49 variation 

50 skew 

51 kurtosis 

52 normaltest 

53 

54Altered Versions 

55----------------

62 tsem

215 

216def _chk_asarray(a, axis): 

217 if axis is None: 

218 a = np.ravel(a) 

219 outaxis = 0 

220 else: 

221 a = np.asarray(a) 

222 outaxis = axis 

223 

224 if a.ndim == 0: 

225 a = np.atleast_1d(a) 

226 

227 return a, outaxis 

228 

229 

230def _chk2_asarray(a, b, axis): 

231 if axis is None: 

232 a = np.ravel(a) 

233 b = np.ravel(b) 

234 outaxis = 0 

235 else: 

236 a = np.asarray(a) 

237 b = np.asarray(b) 

238 outaxis = axis 

239 

240 if a.ndim == 0: 

241 a = np.atleast_1d(a) 

242 if b.ndim == 0: 

243 b = np.atleast_1d(b) 

244 

245 return a, b, outaxis 

246 

247 

248def _contains_nan(a, nan_policy='propagate'): 

249 policies = ['propagate', 'raise', 'omit'] 

250 if nan_policy not in policies: 

251 raise ValueError("nan_policy must be one of {%s}" % 

252 ', '.join("'%s'" % s for s in policies)) 

253 try: 

254 # Calling np.sum to avoid creating a huge array into memory 

255 # e.g. np.isnan(a).any() 

256 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

257 contains_nan = np.isnan(np.sum(a)) 

258 except TypeError: 

259 # This can happen when attempting to sum things which are not 

260 # numbers (e.g. as in the function `mode`). Try an alternative method: 

261 try: 

262 contains_nan = np.nan in set(a.ravel()) 

263 except TypeError: 

264 # Don't know what to do. Fall back to omitting nan values and 

265 # issue a warning. 

266 contains_nan = False 

267 nan_policy = 'omit' 

268 warnings.warn("The input array could not be properly checked for nan " 

269 "values. nan values will be ignored.", RuntimeWarning) 

270 

271 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'raise': 

272 raise ValueError("The input contains nan values") 

273 

274 return (contains_nan, nan_policy) 

275 

276 

277def gmean(a, axis=0, dtype=None): 

278 """ 

279 Compute the geometric mean along the specified axis. 

280 

281 Return the geometric average of the array elements. 

282 That is: n-th root of (x1 * x2 * ... * xn) 

283 

284 Parameters 

285 ---------- 

286 a : array_like 

287 Input array or object that can be converted to an array. 

288 axis : int or None, optional 

289 Axis along which the geometric mean is computed. Default is 0. 

290 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

291 dtype : dtype, optional 

292 Type of the returned array and of the accumulator in which the 

293 elements are summed. If dtype is not specified, it defaults to the 

294 dtype of a, unless a has an integer dtype with a precision less than 

295 that of the default platform integer. In that case, the default 

296 platform integer is used. 

297 

298 Returns 

299 ------- 

300 gmean : ndarray 

301 See `dtype` parameter above. 

302 

303 See Also 

304 -------- 

305 numpy.mean : Arithmetic average 

306 numpy.average : Weighted average 

307 hmean : Harmonic mean 

308 

309 Notes 

310 ----- 

311 The geometric average is computed over a single dimension of the input 

312 array, axis=0 by default, or all values in the array if axis=None. 

313 float64 intermediate and return values are used for integer inputs. 

314 

315 Use masked arrays to ignore any non-finite values in the input or that 

316 arise in the calculations such as Not a Number and infinity because masked 

317 arrays automatically mask any non-finite values. 

318 

319 Examples 

320 -------- 

321 >>> from scipy.stats import gmean 

322 >>> gmean([1, 4]) 

323 2.0 

324 >>> gmean([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) 

325 3.3800151591412964 

326 

327 """ 

328 if not isinstance(a, np.ndarray): 

329 # if not an ndarray object attempt to convert it 

330 log_a = np.log(np.array(a, dtype=dtype)) 

331 elif dtype: 

332 # Must change the default dtype allowing array type 

333 if isinstance(a, np.ma.MaskedArray): 

334 log_a = np.log(np.ma.asarray(a, dtype=dtype)) 

335 else: 

336 log_a = np.log(np.asarray(a, dtype=dtype)) 

337 else: 

338 log_a = np.log(a) 

339 return np.exp(log_a.mean(axis=axis)) 

340 

341 

342def hmean(a, axis=0, dtype=None): 

343 """ 

344 Calculate the harmonic mean along the specified axis. 

345 

346 That is: n / (1/x1 + 1/x2 + ... + 1/xn) 

347 

348 Parameters 

349 ---------- 

350 a : array_like 

351 Input array, masked array or object that can be converted to an array. 

352 axis : int or None, optional 

353 Axis along which the harmonic mean is computed. Default is 0. 

354 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

355 dtype : dtype, optional 

356 Type of the returned array and of the accumulator in which the 

357 elements are summed. If `dtype` is not specified, it defaults to the 

358 dtype of `a`, unless `a` has an integer `dtype` with a precision less 

359 than that of the default platform integer. In that case, the default 

360 platform integer is used. 

361 

362 Returns 

363 ------- 

364 hmean : ndarray 

365 See `dtype` parameter above. 

366 

367 See Also 

368 -------- 

369 numpy.mean : Arithmetic average 

370 numpy.average : Weighted average 

371 gmean : Geometric mean 

372 

373 Notes 

374 ----- 

375 The harmonic mean is computed over a single dimension of the input 

376 array, axis=0 by default, or all values in the array if axis=None. 

377 float64 intermediate and return values are used for integer inputs. 

378 

379 Use masked arrays to ignore any non-finite values in the input or that 

380 arise in the calculations such as Not a Number and infinity. 

381 

382 Examples 

383 -------- 

384 >>> from scipy.stats import hmean 

385 >>> hmean([1, 4]) 

386 1.6000000000000001 

387 >>> hmean([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) 

388 2.6997245179063363 

389 

390 """ 

391 if not isinstance(a, np.ndarray): 

392 a = np.array(a, dtype=dtype) 

393 if np.all(a >= 0): 

394 # Harmonic mean only defined if greater than or equal to to zero. 

395 if isinstance(a, np.ma.MaskedArray): 

396 size = a.count(axis) 

397 else: 

398 if axis is None: 

399 a = a.ravel() 

400 size = a.shape[0] 

401 else: 

402 size = a.shape[axis] 

403 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'): 

404 return size / np.sum(1.0 / a, axis=axis, dtype=dtype) 

405 else: 

406 raise ValueError("Harmonic mean only defined if all elements greater " 

407 "than or equal to zero") 

408 

409 

410ModeResult = namedtuple('ModeResult', ('mode', 'count')) 

411 

412 

413def mode(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

414 """ 

415 Return an array of the modal (most common) value in the passed array. 

416 

417 If there is more than one such value, only the smallest is returned. 

418 The bin-count for the modal bins is also returned. 

419 

420 Parameters 

421 ---------- 

422 a : array_like 

423 n-dimensional array of which to find mode(s). 

424 axis : int or None, optional 

425 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 

426 the whole array `a`. 

427 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

428 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

429 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

430 

431 * 'propagate': returns nan 

432 * 'raise': throws an error 

433 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

434 

435 Returns 

436 ------- 

437 mode : ndarray 

438 Array of modal values. 

439 count : ndarray 

440 Array of counts for each mode. 

441 

442 Examples 

443 -------- 

444 >>> a = np.array([[6, 8, 3, 0], 

445 ... [3, 2, 1, 7], 

446 ... [8, 1, 8, 4], 

447 ... [5, 3, 0, 5], 

448 ... [4, 7, 5, 9]]) 

449 >>> from scipy import stats 

450 >>> stats.mode(a) 

451 (array([[3, 1, 0, 0]]), array([[1, 1, 1, 1]])) 

452 

453 To get mode of whole array, specify ``axis=None``: 

454 

455 >>> stats.mode(a, axis=None) 

456 (array([3]), array([3])) 

457 

458 """ 

459 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

460 if a.size == 0: 

461 return ModeResult(np.array([]), np.array([])) 

462 

463 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

464 

465 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

466 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

467 return mstats_basic.mode(a, axis) 

468 

469 if a.dtype == object and np.nan in set(a.ravel()): 

470 # Fall back to a slower method since np.unique does not work with NaN 

471 scores = set(np.ravel(a)) # get ALL unique values 

472 testshape = list(a.shape) 

473 testshape[axis] = 1 

474 oldmostfreq = np.zeros(testshape, dtype=a.dtype) 

475 oldcounts = np.zeros(testshape, dtype=int) 

476 

477 for score in scores: 

478 template = (a == score) 

479 counts = np.expand_dims(np.sum(template, axis), axis) 

480 mostfrequent = np.where(counts > oldcounts, score, oldmostfreq) 

481 oldcounts = np.maximum(counts, oldcounts) 

482 oldmostfreq = mostfrequent 

483 

484 return ModeResult(mostfrequent, oldcounts) 

485 

486 def _mode1D(a): 

487 vals, cnts = np.unique(a, return_counts=True) 

488 return vals[cnts.argmax()], cnts.max() 

489 

490 # np.apply_along_axis will convert the _mode1D tuples to a numpy array, casting types in the process 

491 # This recreates the results without that issue 

492 # View of a, rotated so the requested axis is last 

493 in_dims = list(range(a.ndim)) 

494 a_view = np.transpose(a, in_dims[:axis] + in_dims[axis+1:] + [axis]) 

495 

496 inds = np.ndindex(a_view.shape[:-1]) 

497 modes = np.empty(a_view.shape[:-1], dtype=a.dtype) 

498 counts = np.zeros(a_view.shape[:-1], dtype=np.int) 

499 for ind in inds: 

500 modes[ind], counts[ind] = _mode1D(a_view[ind]) 

501 newshape = list(a.shape) 

502 newshape[axis] = 1 

503 return ModeResult(modes.reshape(newshape), counts.reshape(newshape)) 

504 

505 

506def _mask_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive): 

507 """Mask an array for values outside of given limits. 

508 

509 This is primarily a utility function. 

510 

511 Parameters 

512 ---------- 

513 a : array 

514 limits : (float or None, float or None) 

515 A tuple consisting of the (lower limit, upper limit). Values in the 

516 input array less than the lower limit or greater than the upper limit 

517 will be masked out. None implies no limit. 

518 inclusive : (bool, bool) 

519 A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag). These flags 

520 determine whether values exactly equal to lower or upper are allowed. 

521 

522 Returns 

523 ------- 

524 A MaskedArray. 

525 

526 Raises 

527 ------ 

528 A ValueError if there are no values within the given limits. 

529 

530 """ 

531 lower_limit, upper_limit = limits 

532 lower_include, upper_include = inclusive 

533 am = ma.MaskedArray(a) 

534 if lower_limit is not None: 

535 if lower_include: 

536 am = ma.masked_less(am, lower_limit) 

537 else: 

538 am = ma.masked_less_equal(am, lower_limit) 

539 

540 if upper_limit is not None: 

541 if upper_include: 

542 am = ma.masked_greater(am, upper_limit) 

543 else: 

544 am = ma.masked_greater_equal(am, upper_limit) 

545 

546 if am.count() == 0: 

547 raise ValueError("No array values within given limits") 

548 

549 return am 

550 

551 

552def tmean(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=None): 

553 """ 

554 Compute the trimmed mean. 

555 

556 This function finds the arithmetic mean of given values, ignoring values 

557 outside the given `limits`. 

558 

559 Parameters 

560 ---------- 

561 a : array_like 

562 Array of values. 

563 limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 

564 Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 

565 upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None (default), then all 

566 values are used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be 

567 None representing a half-open interval. 

568 inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 

569 A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag). These flags 

570 determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 

571 are included. The default value is (True, True). 

572 axis : int or None, optional 

573 Axis along which to compute test. Default is None. 

574 

575 Returns 

576 ------- 

577 tmean : float 

578 Trimmed mean. 

579 

580 See Also 

581 -------- 

582 trim_mean : Returns mean after trimming a proportion from both tails. 

583 

584 Examples 

585 -------- 

586 >>> from scipy import stats 

587 >>> x = np.arange(20) 

588 >>> stats.tmean(x) 

589 9.5 

590 >>> stats.tmean(x, (3,17)) 

591 10.0 

592 

593 """ 

594 a = asarray(a) 

595 if limits is None: 

596 return np.mean(a, None) 

597 

598 am = _mask_to_limits(a.ravel(), limits, inclusive) 

599 return am.mean(axis=axis) 

600 

601 

602def tvar(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1): 

603 """ 

604 Compute the trimmed variance. 

605 

606 This function computes the sample variance of an array of values, 

607 while ignoring values which are outside of given `limits`. 

608 

609 Parameters 

610 ---------- 

611 a : array_like 

612 Array of values. 

613 limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 

614 Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 

615 upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are 

616 used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None 

617 representing a half-open interval. The default value is None. 

618 inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 

619 A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag). These flags 

620 determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 

621 are included. The default value is (True, True). 

622 axis : int or None, optional 

623 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 

624 whole array `a`. 

625 ddof : int, optional 

626 Delta degrees of freedom. Default is 1. 

627 

628 Returns 

629 ------- 

630 tvar : float 

631 Trimmed variance. 

632 

633 Notes 

634 ----- 

635 `tvar` computes the unbiased sample variance, i.e. it uses a correction 

636 factor ``n / (n - 1)``. 

637 

638 Examples 

639 -------- 

640 >>> from scipy import stats 

641 >>> x = np.arange(20) 

642 >>> stats.tvar(x) 

643 35.0 

644 >>> stats.tvar(x, (3,17)) 

645 20.0 

646 

647 """ 

648 a = asarray(a) 

649 a = a.astype(float) 

650 if limits is None: 

651 return a.var(ddof=ddof, axis=axis) 

652 am = _mask_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive) 

653 amnan = am.filled(fill_value=np.nan) 

654 return np.nanvar(amnan, ddof=ddof, axis=axis) 

655 

656 

657def tmin(a, lowerlimit=None, axis=0, inclusive=True, nan_policy='propagate'): 

658 """ 

659 Compute the trimmed minimum. 

660 

661 This function finds the miminum value of an array `a` along the 

662 specified axis, but only considering values greater than a specified 

663 lower limit. 

664 

665 Parameters 

666 ---------- 

667 a : array_like 

668 Array of values. 

669 lowerlimit : None or float, optional 

670 Values in the input array less than the given limit will be ignored. 

671 When lowerlimit is None, then all values are used. The default value 

672 is None. 

673 axis : int or None, optional 

674 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 

675 whole array `a`. 

676 inclusive : {True, False}, optional 

677 This flag determines whether values exactly equal to the lower limit 

678 are included. The default value is True. 

679 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

680 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

681 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

682 

683 * 'propagate': returns nan 

684 * 'raise': throws an error 

685 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

686 

687 Returns 

688 ------- 

689 tmin : float, int or ndarray 

690 Trimmed minimum. 

691 

692 Examples 

693 -------- 

694 >>> from scipy import stats 

695 >>> x = np.arange(20) 

696 >>> stats.tmin(x) 

697 0 

698 

699 >>> stats.tmin(x, 13) 

700 13 

701 

702 >>> stats.tmin(x, 13, inclusive=False) 

703 14 

704 

705 """ 

706 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

707 am = _mask_to_limits(a, (lowerlimit, None), (inclusive, False)) 

708 

709 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(am, nan_policy) 

710 

711 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

712 am = ma.masked_invalid(am) 

713 

714 res = ma.minimum.reduce(am, axis).data 

715 if res.ndim == 0: 

716 return res[()] 

717 return res 

718 

719 

720def tmax(a, upperlimit=None, axis=0, inclusive=True, nan_policy='propagate'): 

721 """ 

722 Compute the trimmed maximum. 

723 

724 This function computes the maximum value of an array along a given axis, 

725 while ignoring values larger than a specified upper limit. 

726 

727 Parameters 

728 ---------- 

729 a : array_like 

730 Array of values. 

731 upperlimit : None or float, optional 

732 Values in the input array greater than the given limit will be ignored. 

733 When upperlimit is None, then all values are used. The default value 

734 is None. 

735 axis : int or None, optional 

736 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 

737 whole array `a`. 

738 inclusive : {True, False}, optional 

739 This flag determines whether values exactly equal to the upper limit 

740 are included. The default value is True. 

741 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

742 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

743 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

744 

745 * 'propagate': returns nan 

746 * 'raise': throws an error 

747 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

748 

749 Returns 

750 ------- 

751 tmax : float, int or ndarray 

752 Trimmed maximum. 

753 

754 Examples 

755 -------- 

756 >>> from scipy import stats 

757 >>> x = np.arange(20) 

758 >>> stats.tmax(x) 

759 19 

760 

761 >>> stats.tmax(x, 13) 

762 13 

763 

764 >>> stats.tmax(x, 13, inclusive=False) 

765 12 

766 

767 """ 

768 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

769 am = _mask_to_limits(a, (None, upperlimit), (False, inclusive)) 

770 

771 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(am, nan_policy) 

772 

773 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

774 am = ma.masked_invalid(am) 

775 

776 res = ma.maximum.reduce(am, axis).data 

777 if res.ndim == 0: 

778 return res[()] 

779 return res 

780 

781 

782def tstd(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1): 

783 """ 

784 Compute the trimmed sample standard deviation. 

785 

786 This function finds the sample standard deviation of given values, 

787 ignoring values outside the given `limits`. 

788 

789 Parameters 

790 ---------- 

791 a : array_like 

792 Array of values. 

793 limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 

794 Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 

795 upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are 

796 used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None 

797 representing a half-open interval. The default value is None. 

798 inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 

799 A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag). These flags 

800 determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 

801 are included. The default value is (True, True). 

802 axis : int or None, optional 

803 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 

804 whole array `a`. 

805 ddof : int, optional 

806 Delta degrees of freedom. Default is 1. 

807 

808 Returns 

809 ------- 

810 tstd : float 

811 Trimmed sample standard deviation. 

812 

813 Notes 

814 ----- 

815 `tstd` computes the unbiased sample standard deviation, i.e. it uses a 

816 correction factor ``n / (n - 1)``. 

817 

818 Examples 

819 -------- 

820 >>> from scipy import stats 

821 >>> x = np.arange(20) 

822 >>> stats.tstd(x) 

823 5.9160797830996161 

824 >>> stats.tstd(x, (3,17)) 

825 4.4721359549995796 

826 

827 """ 

828 return np.sqrt(tvar(a, limits, inclusive, axis, ddof)) 

829 

830 

831def tsem(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1): 

832 """ 

833 Compute the trimmed standard error of the mean. 

834 

835 This function finds the standard error of the mean for given 

836 values, ignoring values outside the given `limits`. 

837 

838 Parameters 

839 ---------- 

840 a : array_like 

841 Array of values. 

842 limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 

843 Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 

844 upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are 

845 used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None 

846 representing a half-open interval. The default value is None. 

847 inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 

848 A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag). These flags 

849 determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 

850 are included. The default value is (True, True). 

851 axis : int or None, optional 

852 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 

853 whole array `a`. 

854 ddof : int, optional 

855 Delta degrees of freedom. Default is 1. 

856 

857 Returns 

858 ------- 

859 tsem : float 

860 Trimmed standard error of the mean. 

861 

862 Notes 

863 ----- 

864 `tsem` uses unbiased sample standard deviation, i.e. it uses a 

865 correction factor ``n / (n - 1)``. 

866 

867 Examples 

868 -------- 

869 >>> from scipy import stats 

870 >>> x = np.arange(20) 

871 >>> stats.tsem(x) 

872 1.3228756555322954 

873 >>> stats.tsem(x, (3,17)) 

874 1.1547005383792515 

875 

876 """ 

877 a = np.asarray(a).ravel() 

878 if limits is None: 

879 return a.std(ddof=ddof) / np.sqrt(a.size) 

880 

881 am = _mask_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive) 

882 sd = np.sqrt(np.ma.var(am, ddof=ddof, axis=axis)) 

883 return sd / np.sqrt(am.count()) 

884 

885 

886##################################### 

887# MOMENTS # 

888##################################### 

889 

890def moment(a, moment=1, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

891 r""" 

892 Calculate the nth moment about the mean for a sample. 

893 

894 A moment is a specific quantitative measure of the shape of a set of 

895 points. It is often used to calculate coefficients of skewness and kurtosis 

896 due to its close relationship with them. 

897 

898 Parameters 

899 ---------- 

900 a : array_like 

901 Input array. 

902 moment : int or array_like of ints, optional 

903 Order of central moment that is returned. Default is 1. 

904 axis : int or None, optional 

905 Axis along which the central moment is computed. Default is 0. 

906 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

907 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

908 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

909 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

910 

911 * 'propagate': returns nan 

912 * 'raise': throws an error 

913 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

914 

915 Returns 

916 ------- 

917 n-th central moment : ndarray or float 

918 The appropriate moment along the given axis or over all values if axis 

919 is None. The denominator for the moment calculation is the number of 

920 observations, no degrees of freedom correction is done. 

921 

922 See Also 

923 -------- 

924 kurtosis, skew, describe 

925 

926 Notes 

927 ----- 

928 The k-th central moment of a data sample is: 

929 

930 .. math:: 

931 

932 m_k = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})^k 

933 

934 Where n is the number of samples and x-bar is the mean. This function uses 

935 exponentiation by squares [1]_ for efficiency. 

936 

937 References 

938 ---------- 

939 .. [1] https://eli.thegreenplace.net/2009/03/21/efficient-integer-exponentiation-algorithms 

940 

941 Examples 

942 -------- 

943 >>> from scipy.stats import moment 

944 >>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], moment=1) 

945 0.0 

946 >>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], moment=2) 

947 2.0 

948 

949 """ 

950 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

951 

952 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

953 

954 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

955 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

956 return mstats_basic.moment(a, moment, axis) 

957 

958 if a.size == 0: 

959 # empty array, return nan(s) with shape matching `moment` 

960 if np.isscalar(moment): 

961 return np.nan 

962 else: 

963 return np.full(np.asarray(moment).shape, np.nan, dtype=np.float64) 

964 

965 # for array_like moment input, return a value for each. 

966 if not np.isscalar(moment): 

967 mmnt = [_moment(a, i, axis) for i in moment] 

968 return np.array(mmnt) 

969 else: 

970 return _moment(a, moment, axis) 

971 

972 

973def _moment(a, moment, axis): 

974 if np.abs(moment - np.round(moment)) > 0: 

975 raise ValueError("All moment parameters must be integers") 

976 

977 if moment == 0: 

978 # When moment equals 0, the result is 1, by definition. 

979 shape = list(a.shape) 

980 del shape[axis] 

981 if shape: 

982 # return an actual array of the appropriate shape 

983 return np.ones(shape, dtype=float) 

984 else: 

985 # the input was 1D, so return a scalar instead of a rank-0 array 

986 return 1.0 

987 

988 elif moment == 1: 

989 # By definition the first moment about the mean is 0. 

990 shape = list(a.shape) 

991 del shape[axis] 

992 if shape: 

993 # return an actual array of the appropriate shape 

994 return np.zeros(shape, dtype=float) 

995 else: 

996 # the input was 1D, so return a scalar instead of a rank-0 array 

997 return np.float64(0.0) 

998 else: 

999 # Exponentiation by squares: form exponent sequence 

1000 n_list = [moment] 

1001 current_n = moment 

1002 while current_n > 2: 

1003 if current_n % 2: 

1004 current_n = (current_n - 1) / 2 

1005 else: 

1006 current_n /= 2 

1007 n_list.append(current_n) 

1008 

1009 # Starting point for exponentiation by squares 

1010 a_zero_mean = a - np.expand_dims(np.mean(a, axis), axis) 

1011 if n_list[-1] == 1: 

1012 s = a_zero_mean.copy() 

1013 else: 

1014 s = a_zero_mean**2 

1015 

1016 # Perform multiplications 

1017 for n in n_list[-2::-1]: 

1018 s = s**2 

1019 if n % 2: 

1020 s *= a_zero_mean 

1021 return np.mean(s, axis) 

1022 

1023 

1024def variation(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1025 """ 

1026 Compute the coefficient of variation. 

1027  

1028 The coefficient of variation is the ratio of the biased standard 

1029 deviation to the mean. 

1030 

1031 Parameters 

1032 ---------- 

1033 a : array_like 

1034 Input array. 

1035 axis : int or None, optional 

1036 Axis along which to calculate the coefficient of variation. Default 

1037 is 0. If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

1038 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1039 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

1040 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

1041 

1042 * 'propagate': returns nan 

1043 * 'raise': throws an error 

1044 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

1045 

1046 Returns 

1047 ------- 

1048 variation : ndarray 

1049 The calculated variation along the requested axis. 

1050 

1051 References 

1052 ---------- 

1053 .. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard 

1054 Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New 

1055 York. 2000. 

1056 

1057 Examples 

1058 -------- 

1059 >>> from scipy.stats import variation 

1060 >>> variation([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) 

1061 0.47140452079103173 

1062 

1063 """ 

1064 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1065 

1066 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1067 

1068 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1069 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1070 return mstats_basic.variation(a, axis) 

1071 

1072 return a.std(axis) / a.mean(axis) 

1073 

1074 

1075def skew(a, axis=0, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1076 r""" 

1077 Compute the sample skewness of a data set. 

1078 

1079 For normally distributed data, the skewness should be about zero. For 

1080 unimodal continuous distributions, a skewness value greater than zero means 

1081 that there is more weight in the right tail of the distribution. The 

1082 function `skewtest` can be used to determine if the skewness value 

1083 is close enough to zero, statistically speaking. 

1084 

1085 Parameters 

1086 ---------- 

1087 a : ndarray 

1088 Input array. 

1089 axis : int or None, optional 

1090 Axis along which skewness is calculated. Default is 0. 

1091 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

1092 bias : bool, optional 

1093 If False, then the calculations are corrected for statistical bias. 

1094 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1095 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

1096 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

1097 

1098 * 'propagate': returns nan 

1099 * 'raise': throws an error 

1100 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

1101 

1102 Returns 

1103 ------- 

1104 skewness : ndarray 

1105 The skewness of values along an axis, returning 0 where all values are 

1106 equal. 

1107 

1108 Notes 

1109 ----- 

1110 The sample skewness is computed as the Fisher-Pearson coefficient 

1111 of skewness, i.e. 

1112 

1113 .. math::  

1114 

1115 g_1=\frac{m_3}{m_2^{3/2}} 

1116 

1117 where 

1118 

1119 .. math::  

1120 

1121 m_i=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N(x[n]-\bar{x})^i 

1122 

1123 is the biased sample :math:`i\texttt{th}` central moment, and :math:`\bar{x}` is 

1124 the sample mean. If ``bias`` is False, the calculations are 

1125 corrected for bias and the value computed is the adjusted 

1126 Fisher-Pearson standardized moment coefficient, i.e. 

1127 

1128 .. math::  

1129 

1130 G_1=\frac{k_3}{k_2^{3/2}}= 

1131 \frac{\sqrt{N(N-1)}}{N-2}\frac{m_3}{m_2^{3/2}}. 

1132 

1133 References 

1134 ---------- 

1135 .. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard 

1136 Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New 

1137 York. 2000. 

1138 Section 2.2.24.1 

1139 

1140 Examples 

1141 -------- 

1142 >>> from scipy.stats import skew 

1143 >>> skew([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) 

1144 0.0 

1145 >>> skew([2, 8, 0, 4, 1, 9, 9, 0]) 

1146 0.2650554122698573 

1147 

1148 """ 

1149 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1150 n = a.shape[axis] 

1151 

1152 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1153 

1154 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1155 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1156 return mstats_basic.skew(a, axis, bias) 

1157 

1158 m2 = moment(a, 2, axis) 

1159 m3 = moment(a, 3, axis) 

1160 zero = (m2 == 0) 

1161 vals = _lazywhere(~zero, (m2, m3), 

1162 lambda m2, m3: m3 / m2**1.5, 

1163 0.) 

1164 if not bias: 

1165 can_correct = (n > 2) & (m2 > 0) 

1166 if can_correct.any(): 

1167 m2 = np.extract(can_correct, m2) 

1168 m3 = np.extract(can_correct, m3) 

1169 nval = np.sqrt((n - 1.0) * n) / (n - 2.0) * m3 / m2**1.5 

1170 np.place(vals, can_correct, nval) 

1171 

1172 if vals.ndim == 0: 

1173 return vals.item() 

1174 

1175 return vals 

1176 

1177 

1178def kurtosis(a, axis=0, fisher=True, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1179 """ 

1180 Compute the kurtosis (Fisher or Pearson) of a dataset. 

1181 

1182 Kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by the square of the 

1183 variance. If Fisher's definition is used, then 3.0 is subtracted from 

1184 the result to give 0.0 for a normal distribution. 

1185 

1186 If bias is False then the kurtosis is calculated using k statistics to 

1187 eliminate bias coming from biased moment estimators 

1188 

1189 Use `kurtosistest` to see if result is close enough to normal. 

1190 

1191 Parameters 

1192 ---------- 

1193 a : array 

1194 Data for which the kurtosis is calculated. 

1195 axis : int or None, optional 

1196 Axis along which the kurtosis is calculated. Default is 0. 

1197 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

1198 fisher : bool, optional 

1199 If True, Fisher's definition is used (normal ==> 0.0). If False, 

1200 Pearson's definition is used (normal ==> 3.0). 

1201 bias : bool, optional 

1202 If False, then the calculations are corrected for statistical bias. 

1203 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1204 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan, 

1205 'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan 

1206 values. Default is 'propagate'. 

1207 

1208 Returns 

1209 ------- 

1210 kurtosis : array 

1211 The kurtosis of values along an axis. If all values are equal, 

1212 return -3 for Fisher's definition and 0 for Pearson's definition. 

1213 

1214 References 

1215 ---------- 

1216 .. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard 

1217 Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New 

1218 York. 2000. 

1219 

1220 Examples 

1221 -------- 

1222 In Fisher's definiton, the kurtosis of the normal distribution is zero. 

1223 In the following example, the kurtosis is close to zero, because it was 

1224 calculated from the dataset, not from the continuous distribution. 

1225 

1226 >>> from scipy.stats import norm, kurtosis 

1227 >>> data = norm.rvs(size=1000, random_state=3) 

1228 >>> kurtosis(data) 

1229 -0.06928694200380558 

1230 

1231 The distribution with a higher kurtosis has a heavier tail. 

1232 The zero valued kurtosis of the normal distribution in Fisher's definition 

1233 can serve as a reference point. 

1234 

1235 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

1236 >>> import scipy.stats as stats 

1237 >>> from scipy.stats import kurtosis 

1238 

1239 >>> x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 100) 

1240 >>> ax = plt.subplot() 

1241 >>> distnames = ['laplace', 'norm', 'uniform'] 

1242 

1243 >>> for distname in distnames: 

1244 ... if distname == 'uniform': 

1245 ... dist = getattr(stats, distname)(loc=-2, scale=4) 

1246 ... else: 

1247 ... dist = getattr(stats, distname) 

1248 ... data = dist.rvs(size=1000) 

1249 ... kur = kurtosis(data, fisher=True) 

1250 ... y = dist.pdf(x) 

1251 ... ax.plot(x, y, label="{}, {}".format(distname, round(kur, 3))) 

1252 ... ax.legend() 

1253 

1254 The Laplace distribution has a heavier tail than the normal distribution. 

1255 The uniform distribution (which has negative kurtosis) has the thinnest 

1256 tail. 

1257 

1258 """ 

1259 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1260 

1261 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1262 

1263 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1264 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1265 return mstats_basic.kurtosis(a, axis, fisher, bias) 

1266 

1267 n = a.shape[axis] 

1268 m2 = moment(a, 2, axis) 

1269 m4 = moment(a, 4, axis) 

1270 zero = (m2 == 0) 

1271 olderr = np.seterr(all='ignore') 

1272 try: 

1273 vals = np.where(zero, 0, m4 / m2**2.0) 

1274 finally: 

1275 np.seterr(**olderr) 

1276 

1277 if not bias: 

1278 can_correct = (n > 3) & (m2 > 0) 

1279 if can_correct.any(): 

1280 m2 = np.extract(can_correct, m2) 

1281 m4 = np.extract(can_correct, m4) 

1282 nval = 1.0/(n-2)/(n-3) * ((n**2-1.0)*m4/m2**2.0 - 3*(n-1)**2.0) 

1283 np.place(vals, can_correct, nval + 3.0) 

1284 

1285 if vals.ndim == 0: 

1286 vals = vals.item() # array scalar 

1287 

1288 return vals - 3 if fisher else vals 

1289 

1290 

1291DescribeResult = namedtuple('DescribeResult', 

1292 ('nobs', 'minmax', 'mean', 'variance', 'skewness', 

1293 'kurtosis')) 

1294 

1295 

1296def describe(a, axis=0, ddof=1, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1297 """ 

1298 Compute several descriptive statistics of the passed array. 

1299 

1300 Parameters 

1301 ---------- 

1302 a : array_like 

1303 Input data. 

1304 axis : int or None, optional 

1305 Axis along which statistics are calculated. Default is 0. 

1306 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

1307 ddof : int, optional 

1308 Delta degrees of freedom (only for variance). Default is 1. 

1309 bias : bool, optional 

1310 If False, then the skewness and kurtosis calculations are corrected for 

1311 statistical bias. 

1312 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1313 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

1314 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

1315 

1316 * 'propagate': returns nan 

1317 * 'raise': throws an error 

1318 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

1319 

1320 Returns 

1321 ------- 

1322 nobs : int or ndarray of ints 

1323 Number of observations (length of data along `axis`). 

1324 When 'omit' is chosen as nan_policy, each column is counted separately. 

1325 minmax: tuple of ndarrays or floats 

1326 Minimum and maximum value of data array. 

1327 mean : ndarray or float 

1328 Arithmetic mean of data along axis. 

1329 variance : ndarray or float 

1330 Unbiased variance of the data along axis, denominator is number of 

1331 observations minus one. 

1332 skewness : ndarray or float 

1333 Skewness, based on moment calculations with denominator equal to 

1334 the number of observations, i.e. no degrees of freedom correction. 

1335 kurtosis : ndarray or float 

1336 Kurtosis (Fisher). The kurtosis is normalized so that it is 

1337 zero for the normal distribution. No degrees of freedom are used. 

1338 

1339 See Also 

1340 -------- 

1341 skew, kurtosis 

1342 

1343 Examples 

1344 -------- 

1345 >>> from scipy import stats 

1346 >>> a = np.arange(10) 

1347 >>> stats.describe(a) 

1348 DescribeResult(nobs=10, minmax=(0, 9), mean=4.5, variance=9.166666666666666, 

1349 skewness=0.0, kurtosis=-1.2242424242424244) 

1350 >>> b = [[1, 2], [3, 4]] 

1351 >>> stats.describe(b) 

1352 DescribeResult(nobs=2, minmax=(array([1, 2]), array([3, 4])), 

1353 mean=array([2., 3.]), variance=array([2., 2.]), 

1354 skewness=array([0., 0.]), kurtosis=array([-2., -2.])) 

1355 

1356 """ 

1357 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1358 

1359 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1360 

1361 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1362 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1363 return mstats_basic.describe(a, axis, ddof, bias) 

1364 

1365 if a.size == 0: 

1366 raise ValueError("The input must not be empty.") 

1367 n = a.shape[axis] 

1368 mm = (np.min(a, axis=axis), np.max(a, axis=axis)) 

1369 m = np.mean(a, axis=axis) 

1370 v = np.var(a, axis=axis, ddof=ddof) 

1371 sk = skew(a, axis, bias=bias) 

1372 kurt = kurtosis(a, axis, bias=bias) 

1373 

1374 return DescribeResult(n, mm, m, v, sk, kurt) 

1375 

1376##################################### 

1377# NORMALITY TESTS # 

1378##################################### 

1379 

1380 

1381SkewtestResult = namedtuple('SkewtestResult', ('statistic', 'pvalue')) 

1382 

1383 

1384def skewtest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1385 """ 

1386 Test whether the skew is different from the normal distribution. 

1387 

1388 This function tests the null hypothesis that the skewness of 

1389 the population that the sample was drawn from is the same 

1390 as that of a corresponding normal distribution. 

1391 

1392 Parameters 

1393 ---------- 

1394 a : array 

1395 The data to be tested. 

1396 axis : int or None, optional 

1397 Axis along which statistics are calculated. Default is 0. 

1398 If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

1399 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1400 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

1401 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

1402 

1403 * 'propagate': returns nan 

1404 * 'raise': throws an error 

1405 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

1406 

1407 Returns 

1408 ------- 

1409 statistic : float 

1410 The computed z-score for this test. 

1411 pvalue : float 

1412 Two-sided p-value for the hypothesis test. 

1413 

1414 Notes 

1415 ----- 

1416 The sample size must be at least 8. 

1417 

1418 References 

1419 ---------- 

1420 .. [1] R. B. D'Agostino, A. J. Belanger and R. B. D'Agostino Jr., 

1421 "A suggestion for using powerful and informative tests of 

1422 normality", American Statistician 44, pp. 316-321, 1990. 

1423 

1424 Examples 

1425 -------- 

1426 >>> from scipy.stats import skewtest 

1427 >>> skewtest([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]) 

1428 SkewtestResult(statistic=1.0108048609177787, pvalue=0.3121098361421897) 

1429 >>> skewtest([2, 8, 0, 4, 1, 9, 9, 0]) 

1430 SkewtestResult(statistic=0.44626385374196975, pvalue=0.6554066631275459) 

1431 >>> skewtest([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8000]) 

1432 SkewtestResult(statistic=3.571773510360407, pvalue=0.0003545719905823133) 

1433 >>> skewtest([100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 101]) 

1434 SkewtestResult(statistic=3.5717766638478072, pvalue=0.000354567720281634) 

1435 

1436 """ 

1437 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1438 

1439 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1440 

1441 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1442 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1443 return mstats_basic.skewtest(a, axis) 

1444 

1445 if axis is None: 

1446 a = np.ravel(a) 

1447 axis = 0 

1448 b2 = skew(a, axis) 

1449 n = a.shape[axis] 

1450 if n < 8: 

1451 raise ValueError( 

1452 "skewtest is not valid with less than 8 samples; %i samples" 

1453 " were given." % int(n)) 

1454 y = b2 * math.sqrt(((n + 1) * (n + 3)) / (6.0 * (n - 2))) 

1455 beta2 = (3.0 * (n**2 + 27*n - 70) * (n+1) * (n+3) / 

1456 ((n-2.0) * (n+5) * (n+7) * (n+9))) 

1457 W2 = -1 + math.sqrt(2 * (beta2 - 1)) 

1458 delta = 1 / math.sqrt(0.5 * math.log(W2)) 

1459 alpha = math.sqrt(2.0 / (W2 - 1)) 

1460 y = np.where(y == 0, 1, y) 

1461 Z = delta * np.log(y / alpha + np.sqrt((y / alpha)**2 + 1)) 

1462 

1463 return SkewtestResult(Z, 2 * distributions.norm.sf(np.abs(Z))) 

1464 

1465 

1466KurtosistestResult = namedtuple('KurtosistestResult', ('statistic', 'pvalue')) 

1467 

1468 

1469def kurtosistest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1470 """ 

1471 Test whether a dataset has normal kurtosis. 

1472 

1473 This function tests the null hypothesis that the kurtosis 

1474 of the population from which the sample was drawn is that 

1475 of the normal distribution: ``kurtosis = 3(n-1)/(n+1)``. 

1476 

1477 Parameters 

1478 ---------- 

1479 a : array 

1480 Array of the sample data. 

1481 axis : int or None, optional 

1482 Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None, 

1483 compute over the whole array `a`. 

1484 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1485 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

1486 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

1487 

1488 * 'propagate': returns nan 

1489 * 'raise': throws an error 

1490 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

1491 

1492 Returns 

1493 ------- 

1494 statistic : float 

1495 The computed z-score for this test. 

1496 pvalue : float 

1497 The two-sided p-value for the hypothesis test. 

1498 

1499 Notes 

1500 ----- 

1501 Valid only for n>20. This function uses the method described in [1]_. 

1502 

1503 References 

1504 ---------- 

1505 .. [1] see e.g. F. J. Anscombe, W. J. Glynn, "Distribution of the kurtosis 

1506 statistic b2 for normal samples", Biometrika, vol. 70, pp. 227-234, 1983. 

1507 

1508 Examples 

1509 -------- 

1510 >>> from scipy.stats import kurtosistest 

1511 >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20))) 

1512 KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.08804338332528348) 

1513 

1514 >>> np.random.seed(28041990) 

1515 >>> s = np.random.normal(0, 1, 1000) 

1516 >>> kurtosistest(s) 

1517 KurtosistestResult(statistic=1.2317590987707365, pvalue=0.21803908613450895) 

1518 

1519 """ 

1520 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1521 

1522 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1523 

1524 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1525 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1526 return mstats_basic.kurtosistest(a, axis) 

1527 

1528 n = a.shape[axis] 

1529 if n < 5: 

1530 raise ValueError( 

1531 "kurtosistest requires at least 5 observations; %i observations" 

1532 " were given." % int(n)) 

1533 if n < 20: 

1534 warnings.warn("kurtosistest only valid for n>=20 ... continuing " 

1535 "anyway, n=%i" % int(n)) 

1536 b2 = kurtosis(a, axis, fisher=False) 

1537 

1538 E = 3.0*(n-1) / (n+1) 

1539 varb2 = 24.0*n*(n-2)*(n-3) / ((n+1)*(n+1.)*(n+3)*(n+5)) # [1]_ Eq. 1 

1540 x = (b2-E) / np.sqrt(varb2) # [1]_ Eq. 4 

1541 # [1]_ Eq. 2: 

1542 sqrtbeta1 = 6.0*(n*n-5*n+2)/((n+7)*(n+9)) * np.sqrt((6.0*(n+3)*(n+5)) / 

1543 (n*(n-2)*(n-3))) 

1544 # [1]_ Eq. 3: 

1545 A = 6.0 + 8.0/sqrtbeta1 * (2.0/sqrtbeta1 + np.sqrt(1+4.0/(sqrtbeta1**2))) 

1546 term1 = 1 - 2/(9.0*A) 

1547 denom = 1 + x*np.sqrt(2/(A-4.0)) 

1548 term2 = np.sign(denom) * np.where(denom == 0.0, np.nan, 

1549 np.power((1-2.0/A)/np.abs(denom), 1/3.0)) 

1550 if np.any(denom == 0): 

1551 msg = "Test statistic not defined in some cases due to division by " \ 

1552 "zero. Return nan in that case..." 

1553 warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning) 

1554 

1555 Z = (term1 - term2) / np.sqrt(2/(9.0*A)) # [1]_ Eq. 5 

1556 if Z.ndim == 0: 

1557 Z = Z[()] 

1558 

1559 # zprob uses upper tail, so Z needs to be positive 

1560 return KurtosistestResult(Z, 2 * distributions.norm.sf(np.abs(Z))) 

1561 

1562 

1563NormaltestResult = namedtuple('NormaltestResult', ('statistic', 'pvalue')) 

1564 

1565 

1566def normaltest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

1567 """ 

1568 Test whether a sample differs from a normal distribution. 

1569 

1570 This function tests the null hypothesis that a sample comes 

1571 from a normal distribution. It is based on D'Agostino and 

1572 Pearson's [1]_, [2]_ test that combines skew and kurtosis to 

1573 produce an omnibus test of normality. 

1574 

1575 Parameters 

1576 ---------- 

1577 a : array_like 

1578 The array containing the sample to be tested. 

1579 axis : int or None, optional 

1580 Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None, 

1581 compute over the whole array `a`. 

1582 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

1583 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

1584 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

1585 

1586 * 'propagate': returns nan 

1587 * 'raise': throws an error 

1588 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

1589 

1590 Returns 

1591 ------- 

1592 statistic : float or array 

1593 ``s^2 + k^2``, where ``s`` is the z-score returned by `skewtest` and 

1594 ``k`` is the z-score returned by `kurtosistest`. 

1595 pvalue : float or array 

1596 A 2-sided chi squared probability for the hypothesis test. 

1597 

1598 References 

1599 ---------- 

1600 .. [1] D'Agostino, R. B. (1971), "An omnibus test of normality for 

1601 moderate and large sample size", Biometrika, 58, 341-348 

1602 

1603 .. [2] D'Agostino, R. and Pearson, E. S. (1973), "Tests for departure from 

1604 normality", Biometrika, 60, 613-622 

1605 

1606 Examples 

1607 -------- 

1608 >>> from scipy import stats 

1609 >>> pts = 1000 

1610 >>> np.random.seed(28041990) 

1611 >>> a = np.random.normal(0, 1, size=pts) 

1612 >>> b = np.random.normal(2, 1, size=pts) 

1613 >>> x = np.concatenate((a, b)) 

1614 >>> k2, p = stats.normaltest(x) 

1615 >>> alpha = 1e-3 

1616 >>> print("p = {:g}".format(p)) 

1617 p = 3.27207e-11 

1618 >>> if p < alpha: # null hypothesis: x comes from a normal distribution 

1619 ... print("The null hypothesis can be rejected") 

1620 ... else: 

1621 ... print("The null hypothesis cannot be rejected") 

1622 The null hypothesis can be rejected 

1623 

1624 """ 

1625 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

1626 

1627 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

1628 

1629 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

1630 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

1631 return mstats_basic.normaltest(a, axis) 

1632 

1633 s, _ = skewtest(a, axis) 

1634 k, _ = kurtosistest(a, axis) 

1635 k2 = s*s + k*k 

1636 

1637 return NormaltestResult(k2, distributions.chi2.sf(k2, 2)) 

1638 

1639 

1640def jarque_bera(x): 

1641 """ 

1642 Perform the Jarque-Bera goodness of fit test on sample data. 

1643 

1644 The Jarque-Bera test tests whether the sample data has the skewness and 

1645 kurtosis matching a normal distribution. 

1646 

1647 Note that this test only works for a large enough number of data samples 

1648 (>2000) as the test statistic asymptotically has a Chi-squared distribution 

1649 with 2 degrees of freedom. 

1650 

1651 Parameters 

1652 ---------- 

1653 x : array_like 

1654 Observations of a random variable. 

1655 

1656 Returns 

1657 ------- 

1658 jb_value : float 

1659 The test statistic. 

1660 p : float 

1661 The p-value for the hypothesis test. 

1662 

1663 References 

1664 ---------- 

1665 .. [1] Jarque, C. and Bera, A. (1980) "Efficient tests for normality, 

1666 homoscedasticity and serial independence of regression residuals", 

1667 6 Econometric Letters 255-259. 

1668 

1669 Examples 

1670 -------- 

1671 >>> from scipy import stats 

1672 >>> np.random.seed(987654321) 

1673 >>> x = np.random.normal(0, 1, 100000) 

1674 >>> y = np.random.rayleigh(1, 100000) 

1675 >>> stats.jarque_bera(x) 

1676 (4.7165707989581342, 0.09458225503041906) 

1677 >>> stats.jarque_bera(y) 

1678 (6713.7098548143422, 0.0) 

1679 

1680 """ 

1681 x = np.asarray(x) 

1682 n = x.size 

1683 if n == 0: 

1684 raise ValueError('At least one observation is required.') 

1685 

1686 mu = x.mean() 

1687 diffx = x - mu 

1688 skewness = (1 / n * np.sum(diffx**3)) / (1 / n * np.sum(diffx**2))**(3 / 2.) 

1689 kurtosis = (1 / n * np.sum(diffx**4)) / (1 / n * np.sum(diffx**2))**2 

1690 jb_value = n / 6 * (skewness**2 + (kurtosis - 3)**2 / 4) 

1691 p = 1 - distributions.chi2.cdf(jb_value, 2) 

1692 

1693 return jb_value, p 

1694 

1695 

1696##################################### 

1697# FREQUENCY FUNCTIONS # 

1698##################################### 

1699 

1700@np.deprecate(message="`itemfreq` is deprecated and will be removed in a " 

1701 "future version. Use instead `np.unique(..., return_counts=True)`") 

1702def itemfreq(a): 

1703 """ 

1704 Return a 2-D array of item frequencies. 

1705 

1706 Parameters 

1707 ---------- 

1708 a : (N,) array_like 

1709 Input array. 

1710 

1711 Returns 

1712 ------- 

1713 itemfreq : (K, 2) ndarray 

1714 A 2-D frequency table. Column 1 contains sorted, unique values from 

1715 `a`, column 2 contains their respective counts. 

1716 

1717 Examples 

1718 -------- 

1719 >>> from scipy import stats 

1720 >>> a = np.array([1, 1, 5, 0, 1, 2, 2, 0, 1, 4]) 

1721 >>> stats.itemfreq(a) 

1722 array([[ 0., 2.], 

1723 [ 1., 4.], 

1724 [ 2., 2.], 

1725 [ 4., 1.], 

1726 [ 5., 1.]]) 

1727 >>> np.bincount(a) 

1728 array([2, 4, 2, 0, 1, 1]) 

1729 

1730 >>> stats.itemfreq(a/10.) 

1731 array([[ 0. , 2. ], 

1732 [ 0.1, 4. ], 

1733 [ 0.2, 2. ], 

1734 [ 0.4, 1. ], 

1735 [ 0.5, 1. ]]) 

1736 

1737 """ 

1738 items, inv = np.unique(a, return_inverse=True) 

1739 freq = np.bincount(inv) 

1740 return np.array([items, freq]).T 

1741 

1742 

1743def scoreatpercentile(a, per, limit=(), interpolation_method='fraction', 

1744 axis=None): 

1745 """ 

1746 Calculate the score at a given percentile of the input sequence. 

1747 

1748 For example, the score at `per=50` is the median. If the desired quantile 

1749 lies between two data points, we interpolate between them, according to 

1750 the value of `interpolation`. If the parameter `limit` is provided, it 

1751 should be a tuple (lower, upper) of two values. 

1752 

1753 Parameters 

1754 ---------- 

1755 a : array_like 

1756 A 1-D array of values from which to extract score. 

1757 per : array_like 

1758 Percentile(s) at which to extract score. Values should be in range 

1759 [0,100]. 

1760 limit : tuple, optional 

1761 Tuple of two scalars, the lower and upper limits within which to 

1762 compute the percentile. Values of `a` outside 

1763 this (closed) interval will be ignored. 

1764 interpolation_method : {'fraction', 'lower', 'higher'}, optional 

1765 Specifies the interpolation method to use, 

1766 when the desired quantile lies between two data points `i` and `j` 

1767 The following options are available (default is 'fraction'): 

1768 

1769 * 'fraction': ``i + (j - i) * fraction`` where ``fraction`` is the 

1770 fractional part of the index surrounded by ``i`` and ``j`` 

1771 * 'lower': ``i`` 

1772 * 'higher': ``j`` 

1773 

1774 axis : int, optional 

1775 Axis along which the percentiles are computed. Default is None. If 

1776 None, compute over the whole array `a`. 

1777 

1778 Returns 

1779 ------- 

1780 score : float or ndarray 

1781 Score at percentile(s). 

1782 

1783 See Also 

1784 -------- 

1785 percentileofscore, numpy.percentile 

1786 

1787 Notes 

1788 ----- 

1789 This function will become obsolete in the future. 

1790 For NumPy 1.9 and higher, `numpy.percentile` provides all the functionality 

1791 that `scoreatpercentile` provides. And it's significantly faster. 

1792 Therefore it's recommended to use `numpy.percentile` for users that have 

1793 numpy >= 1.9. 

1794 

1795 Examples 

1796 -------- 

1797 >>> from scipy import stats 

1798 >>> a = np.arange(100) 

1799 >>> stats.scoreatpercentile(a, 50) 

1800 49.5 

1801 

1802 """ 

1803 # adapted from NumPy's percentile function. When we require numpy >= 1.8, 

1804 # the implementation of this function can be replaced by np.percentile. 

1805 a = np.asarray(a) 

1806 if a.size == 0: 

1807 # empty array, return nan(s) with shape matching `per` 

1808 if np.isscalar(per): 

1809 return np.nan 

1810 else: 

1811 return np.full(np.asarray(per).shape, np.nan, dtype=np.float64) 

1812 

1813 if limit: 

1814 a = a[(limit[0] <= a) & (a <= limit[1])] 

1815 

1816 sorted_ = np.sort(a, axis=axis) 

1817 if axis is None: 

1818 axis = 0 

1819 

1820 return _compute_qth_percentile(sorted_, per, interpolation_method, axis) 

1821 

1822 

1823# handle sequence of per's without calling sort multiple times 

1824def _compute_qth_percentile(sorted_, per, interpolation_method, axis): 

1825 if not np.isscalar(per): 

1826 score = [_compute_qth_percentile(sorted_, i, 

1827 interpolation_method, axis) 

1828 for i in per] 

1829 return np.array(score) 

1830 

1831 if not (0 <= per <= 100): 

1832 raise ValueError("percentile must be in the range [0, 100]") 

1833 

1834 indexer = [slice(None)] * sorted_.ndim 

1835 idx = per / 100. * (sorted_.shape[axis] - 1) 

1836 

1837 if int(idx) != idx: 

1838 # round fractional indices according to interpolation method 

1839 if interpolation_method == 'lower': 

1840 idx = int(np.floor(idx)) 

1841 elif interpolation_method == 'higher': 

1842 idx = int(np.ceil(idx)) 

1843 elif interpolation_method == 'fraction': 

1844 pass # keep idx as fraction and interpolate 

1845 else: 

1846 raise ValueError("interpolation_method can only be 'fraction', " 

1847 "'lower' or 'higher'") 

1848 

1849 i = int(idx) 

1850 if i == idx: 

1851 indexer[axis] = slice(i, i + 1) 

1852 weights = array(1) 

1853 sumval = 1.0 

1854 else: 

1855 indexer[axis] = slice(i, i + 2) 

1856 j = i + 1 

1857 weights = array([(j - idx), (idx - i)], float) 

1858 wshape = [1] * sorted_.ndim 

1859 wshape[axis] = 2 

1860 weights.shape = wshape 

1861 sumval = weights.sum() 

1862 

1863 # Use np.add.reduce (== np.sum but a little faster) to coerce data type 

1864 return np.add.reduce(sorted_[tuple(indexer)] * weights, axis=axis) / sumval 

1865 

1866 

1867def percentileofscore(a, score, kind='rank'): 

1868 """ 

1869 Compute the percentile rank of a score relative to a list of scores. 

1870 

1871 A `percentileofscore` of, for example, 80% means that 80% of the 

1872 scores in `a` are below the given score. In the case of gaps or 

1873 ties, the exact definition depends on the optional keyword, `kind`. 

1874 

1875 Parameters 

1876 ---------- 

1877 a : array_like 

1878 Array of scores to which `score` is compared. 

1879 score : int or float 

1880 Score that is compared to the elements in `a`. 

1881 kind : {'rank', 'weak', 'strict', 'mean'}, optional 

1882 Specifies the interpretation of the resulting score. 

1883 The following options are available (default is 'rank'): 

1884 

1885 * 'rank': Average percentage ranking of score. In case of multiple 

1886 matches, average the percentage rankings of all matching scores. 

1887 * 'weak': This kind corresponds to the definition of a cumulative 

1888 distribution function. A percentileofscore of 80% means that 80% 

1889 of values are less than or equal to the provided score. 

1890 * 'strict': Similar to "weak", except that only values that are 

1891 strictly less than the given score are counted. 

1892 * 'mean': The average of the "weak" and "strict" scores, often used 

1893 in testing. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percentile_rank 

1894 

1895 Returns 

1896 ------- 

1897 pcos : float 

1898 Percentile-position of score (0-100) relative to `a`. 

1899 

1900 See Also 

1901 -------- 

1902 numpy.percentile 

1903 

1904 Examples 

1905 -------- 

1906 Three-quarters of the given values lie below a given score: 

1907 

1908 >>> from scipy import stats 

1909 >>> stats.percentileofscore([1, 2, 3, 4], 3) 

1910 75.0 

1911 

1912 With multiple matches, note how the scores of the two matches, 0.6 

1913 and 0.8 respectively, are averaged: 

1914 

1915 >>> stats.percentileofscore([1, 2, 3, 3, 4], 3) 

1916 70.0 

1917 

1918 Only 2/5 values are strictly less than 3: 

1919 

1920 >>> stats.percentileofscore([1, 2, 3, 3, 4], 3, kind='strict') 

1921 40.0 

1922 

1923 But 4/5 values are less than or equal to 3: 

1924 

1925 >>> stats.percentileofscore([1, 2, 3, 3, 4], 3, kind='weak') 

1926 80.0 

1927 

1928 The average between the weak and the strict scores is: 

1929 

1930 >>> stats.percentileofscore([1, 2, 3, 3, 4], 3, kind='mean') 

1931 60.0 

1932 

1933 """ 

1934 if np.isnan(score): 

1935 return np.nan 

1936 a = np.asarray(a) 

1937 n = len(a) 

1938 if n == 0: 

1939 return 100.0 

1940 

1941 if kind == 'rank': 

1942 left = np.count_nonzero(a < score) 

1943 right = np.count_nonzero(a <= score) 

1944 pct = (right + left + (1 if right > left else 0)) * 50.0/n 

1945 return pct 

1946 elif kind == 'strict': 

1947 return np.count_nonzero(a < score) / n * 100 

1948 elif kind == 'weak': 

1949 return np.count_nonzero(a <= score) / n * 100 

1950 elif kind == 'mean': 

1951 pct = (np.count_nonzero(a < score) + np.count_nonzero(a <= score)) / n * 50 

1952 return pct 

1953 else: 

1954 raise ValueError("kind can only be 'rank', 'strict', 'weak' or 'mean'") 

1955 

1956 

1957HistogramResult = namedtuple('HistogramResult', 

1958 ('count', 'lowerlimit', 'binsize', 'extrapoints')) 

1959 

1960 

1961def _histogram(a, numbins=10, defaultlimits=None, weights=None, printextras=False): 

1962 """ 

1963 Create a histogram. 

1964  

1965 Separate the range into several bins and return the number of instances 

1966 in each bin. 

1967 

1968 Parameters 

1969 ---------- 

1970 a : array_like 

1971 Array of scores which will be put into bins. 

1972 numbins : int, optional 

1973 The number of bins to use for the histogram. Default is 10. 

1974 defaultlimits : tuple (lower, upper), optional 

1975 The lower and upper values for the range of the histogram. 

1976 If no value is given, a range slightly larger than the range of the 

1977 values in a is used. Specifically ``(a.min() - s, a.max() + s)``, 

1978 where ``s = (1/2)(a.max() - a.min()) / (numbins - 1)``. 

1979 weights : array_like, optional 

1980 The weights for each value in `a`. Default is None, which gives each 

1981 value a weight of 1.0 

1982 printextras : bool, optional 

1983 If True, if there are extra points (i.e. the points that fall outside 

1984 the bin limits) a warning is raised saying how many of those points 

1985 there are. Default is False. 

1986 

1987 Returns 

1988 ------- 

1989 count : ndarray 

1990 Number of points (or sum of weights) in each bin. 

1991 lowerlimit : float 

1992 Lowest value of histogram, the lower limit of the first bin. 

1993 binsize : float 

1994 The size of the bins (all bins have the same size). 

1995 extrapoints : int 

1996 The number of points outside the range of the histogram. 

1997 

1998 See Also 

1999 -------- 

2000 numpy.histogram 

2001 

2002 Notes 

2003 ----- 

2004 This histogram is based on numpy's histogram but has a larger range by 

2005 default if default limits is not set. 

2006 

2007 """ 

2008 a = np.ravel(a) 

2009 if defaultlimits is None: 

2010 if a.size == 0: 

2011 # handle empty arrays. Undetermined range, so use 0-1. 

2012 defaultlimits = (0, 1) 

2013 else: 

2014 # no range given, so use values in `a` 

2015 data_min = a.min() 

2016 data_max = a.max() 

2017 # Have bins extend past min and max values slightly 

2018 s = (data_max - data_min) / (2. * (numbins - 1.)) 

2019 defaultlimits = (data_min - s, data_max + s) 

2020 

2021 # use numpy's histogram method to compute bins 

2022 hist, bin_edges = np.histogram(a, bins=numbins, range=defaultlimits, 

2023 weights=weights) 

2024 # hist are not always floats, convert to keep with old output 

2025 hist = np.array(hist, dtype=float) 

2026 # fixed width for bins is assumed, as numpy's histogram gives 

2027 # fixed width bins for int values for 'bins' 

2028 binsize = bin_edges[1] - bin_edges[0] 

2029 # calculate number of extra points 

2030 extrapoints = len([v for v in a 

2031 if defaultlimits[0] > v or v > defaultlimits[1]]) 

2032 if extrapoints > 0 and printextras: 

2033 warnings.warn("Points outside given histogram range = %s" 

2034 % extrapoints) 

2035 

2036 return HistogramResult(hist, defaultlimits[0], binsize, extrapoints) 

2037 

2038 

2039CumfreqResult = namedtuple('CumfreqResult', 

2040 ('cumcount', 'lowerlimit', 'binsize', 

2041 'extrapoints')) 

2042 

2043 

2044def cumfreq(a, numbins=10, defaultreallimits=None, weights=None): 

2045 """ 

2046 Return a cumulative frequency histogram, using the histogram function. 

2047 

2048 A cumulative histogram is a mapping that counts the cumulative number of 

2049 observations in all of the bins up to the specified bin. 

2050 

2051 Parameters 

2052 ---------- 

2053 a : array_like 

2054 Input array. 

2055 numbins : int, optional 

2056 The number of bins to use for the histogram. Default is 10. 

2057 defaultreallimits : tuple (lower, upper), optional 

2058 The lower and upper values for the range of the histogram. 

2059 If no value is given, a range slightly larger than the range of the 

2060 values in `a` is used. Specifically ``(a.min() - s, a.max() + s)``, 

2061 where ``s = (1/2)(a.max() - a.min()) / (numbins - 1)``. 

2062 weights : array_like, optional 

2063 The weights for each value in `a`. Default is None, which gives each 

2064 value a weight of 1.0 

2065 

2066 Returns 

2067 ------- 

2068 cumcount : ndarray 

2069 Binned values of cumulative frequency. 

2070 lowerlimit : float 

2071 Lower real limit 

2072 binsize : float 

2073 Width of each bin. 

2074 extrapoints : int 

2075 Extra points. 

2076 

2077 Examples 

2078 -------- 

2079 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

2080 >>> from scipy import stats 

2081 >>> x = [1, 4, 2, 1, 3, 1] 

2082 >>> res = stats.cumfreq(x, numbins=4, defaultreallimits=(1.5, 5)) 

2083 >>> res.cumcount 

2084 array([ 1., 2., 3., 3.]) 

2085 >>> res.extrapoints 

2086 3 

2087 

2088 Create a normal distribution with 1000 random values 

2089 

2090 >>> rng = np.random.RandomState(seed=12345) 

2091 >>> samples = stats.norm.rvs(size=1000, random_state=rng) 

2092 

2093 Calculate cumulative frequencies 

2094 

2095 >>> res = stats.cumfreq(samples, numbins=25) 

2096 

2097 Calculate space of values for x 

2098 

2099 >>> x = res.lowerlimit + np.linspace(0, res.binsize*res.cumcount.size, 

2100 ... res.cumcount.size) 

2101 

2102 Plot histogram and cumulative histogram 

2103 

2104 >>> fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 4)) 

2105 >>> ax1 = fig.add_subplot(1, 2, 1) 

2106 >>> ax2 = fig.add_subplot(1, 2, 2) 

2107 >>> ax1.hist(samples, bins=25) 

2108 >>> ax1.set_title('Histogram') 

2109 >>> ax2.bar(x, res.cumcount, width=res.binsize) 

2110 >>> ax2.set_title('Cumulative histogram') 

2111 >>> ax2.set_xlim([x.min(), x.max()]) 

2112 

2113 >>> plt.show() 

2114 

2115 """ 

2116 h, l, b, e = _histogram(a, numbins, defaultreallimits, weights=weights) 

2117 cumhist = np.cumsum(h * 1, axis=0) 

2118 return CumfreqResult(cumhist, l, b, e) 

2119 

2120 

2121RelfreqResult = namedtuple('RelfreqResult', 

2122 ('frequency', 'lowerlimit', 'binsize', 

2123 'extrapoints')) 

2124 

2125 

2126def relfreq(a, numbins=10, defaultreallimits=None, weights=None): 

2127 """ 

2128 Return a relative frequency histogram, using the histogram function. 

2129 

2130 A relative frequency histogram is a mapping of the number of 

2131 observations in each of the bins relative to the total of observations. 

2132 

2133 Parameters 

2134 ---------- 

2135 a : array_like 

2136 Input array. 

2137 numbins : int, optional 

2138 The number of bins to use for the histogram. Default is 10. 

2139 defaultreallimits : tuple (lower, upper), optional 

2140 The lower and upper values for the range of the histogram. 

2141 If no value is given, a range slightly larger than the range of the 

2142 values in a is used. Specifically ``(a.min() - s, a.max() + s)``, 

2143 where ``s = (1/2)(a.max() - a.min()) / (numbins - 1)``. 

2144 weights : array_like, optional 

2145 The weights for each value in `a`. Default is None, which gives each 

2146 value a weight of 1.0 

2147 

2148 Returns 

2149 ------- 

2150 frequency : ndarray 

2151 Binned values of relative frequency. 

2152 lowerlimit : float 

2153 Lower real limit. 

2154 binsize : float 

2155 Width of each bin. 

2156 extrapoints : int 

2157 Extra points. 

2158 

2159 Examples 

2160 -------- 

2161 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

2162 >>> from scipy import stats 

2163 >>> a = np.array([2, 4, 1, 2, 3, 2]) 

2164 >>> res = stats.relfreq(a, numbins=4) 

2165 >>> res.frequency 

2166 array([ 0.16666667, 0.5 , 0.16666667, 0.16666667]) 

2167 >>> np.sum(res.frequency) # relative frequencies should add up to 1 

2168 1.0 

2169 

2170 Create a normal distribution with 1000 random values 

2171 

2172 >>> rng = np.random.RandomState(seed=12345) 

2173 >>> samples = stats.norm.rvs(size=1000, random_state=rng) 

2174 

2175 Calculate relative frequencies 

2176 

2177 >>> res = stats.relfreq(samples, numbins=25) 

2178 

2179 Calculate space of values for x 

2180 

2181 >>> x = res.lowerlimit + np.linspace(0, res.binsize*res.frequency.size, 

2182 ... res.frequency.size) 

2183 

2184 Plot relative frequency histogram 

2185 

2186 >>> fig = plt.figure(figsize=(5, 4)) 

2187 >>> ax = fig.add_subplot(1, 1, 1) 

2188 >>> ax.bar(x, res.frequency, width=res.binsize) 

2189 >>> ax.set_title('Relative frequency histogram') 

2190 >>> ax.set_xlim([x.min(), x.max()]) 

2191 

2192 >>> plt.show() 

2193 

2194 """ 

2195 a = np.asanyarray(a) 

2196 h, l, b, e = _histogram(a, numbins, defaultreallimits, weights=weights) 

2197 h = h / a.shape[0] 

2198 

2199 return RelfreqResult(h, l, b, e) 

2200 

2201 

2202##################################### 

2203# VARIABILITY FUNCTIONS # 

2204##################################### 

2205 

2206def obrientransform(*args): 

2207 """ 

2208 Compute the O'Brien transform on input data (any number of arrays). 

2209 

2210 Used to test for homogeneity of variance prior to running one-way stats. 

2211 Each array in ``*args`` is one level of a factor. 

2212 If `f_oneway` is run on the transformed data and found significant, 

2213 the variances are unequal. From Maxwell and Delaney [1]_, p.112. 

2214 

2215 Parameters 

2216 ---------- 

2217 args : tuple of array_like 

2218 Any number of arrays. 

2219 

2220 Returns 

2221 ------- 

2222 obrientransform : ndarray 

2223 Transformed data for use in an ANOVA. The first dimension 

2224 of the result corresponds to the sequence of transformed 

2225 arrays. If the arrays given are all 1-D of the same length, 

2226 the return value is a 2-D array; otherwise it is a 1-D array 

2227 of type object, with each element being an ndarray. 

2228 

2229 References 

2230 ---------- 

2231 .. [1] S. E. Maxwell and H. D. Delaney, "Designing Experiments and 

2232 Analyzing Data: A Model Comparison Perspective", Wadsworth, 1990. 

2233 

2234 Examples 

2235 -------- 

2236 We'll test the following data sets for differences in their variance. 

2237 

2238 >>> x = [10, 11, 13, 9, 7, 12, 12, 9, 10] 

2239 >>> y = [13, 21, 5, 10, 8, 14, 10, 12, 7, 15] 

2240 

2241 Apply the O'Brien transform to the data. 

2242 

2243 >>> from scipy.stats import obrientransform 

2244 >>> tx, ty = obrientransform(x, y) 

2245 

2246 Use `scipy.stats.f_oneway` to apply a one-way ANOVA test to the 

2247 transformed data. 

2248 

2249 >>> from scipy.stats import f_oneway 

2250 >>> F, p = f_oneway(tx, ty) 

2251 >>> p 

2252 0.1314139477040335 

2253 

2254 If we require that ``p < 0.05`` for significance, we cannot conclude 

2255 that the variances are different. 

2256  

2257 """ 

2258 TINY = np.sqrt(np.finfo(float).eps) 

2259 

2260 # `arrays` will hold the transformed arguments. 

2261 arrays = [] 

2262 

2263 for arg in args: 

2264 a = np.asarray(arg) 

2265 n = len(a) 

2266 mu = np.mean(a) 

2267 sq = (a - mu)**2 

2268 sumsq = sq.sum() 

2269 

2270 # The O'Brien transform. 

2271 t = ((n - 1.5) * n * sq - 0.5 * sumsq) / ((n - 1) * (n - 2)) 

2272 

2273 # Check that the mean of the transformed data is equal to the 

2274 # original variance. 

2275 var = sumsq / (n - 1) 

2276 if abs(var - np.mean(t)) > TINY: 

2277 raise ValueError('Lack of convergence in obrientransform.') 

2278 

2279 arrays.append(t) 

2280 

2281 return np.array(arrays) 

2282 

2283 

2284def sem(a, axis=0, ddof=1, nan_policy='propagate'): 

2285 """ 

2286 Compute standard error of the mean. 

2287  

2288 Calculate the standard error of the mean (or standard error of 

2289 measurement) of the values in the input array. 

2290 

2291 Parameters 

2292 ---------- 

2293 a : array_like 

2294 An array containing the values for which the standard error is 

2295 returned. 

2296 axis : int or None, optional 

2297 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 

2298 the whole array `a`. 

2299 ddof : int, optional 

2300 Delta degrees-of-freedom. How many degrees of freedom to adjust 

2301 for bias in limited samples relative to the population estimate 

2302 of variance. Defaults to 1. 

2303 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

2304 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 

2305 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 

2306 

2307 * 'propagate': returns nan 

2308 * 'raise': throws an error 

2309 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 

2310 

2311 Returns 

2312 ------- 

2313 s : ndarray or float 

2314 The standard error of the mean in the sample(s), along the input axis. 

2315 

2316 Notes 

2317 ----- 

2318 The default value for `ddof` is different to the default (0) used by other 

2319 ddof containing routines, such as np.std and np.nanstd. 

2320 

2321 Examples 

2322 -------- 

2323 Find standard error along the first axis: 

2324 

2325 >>> from scipy import stats 

2326 >>> a = np.arange(20).reshape(5,4) 

2327 >>> stats.sem(a) 

2328 array([ 2.8284, 2.8284, 2.8284, 2.8284]) 

2329 

2330 Find standard error across the whole array, using n degrees of freedom: 

2331 

2332 >>> stats.sem(a, axis=None, ddof=0) 

2333 1.2893796958227628 

2334 

2335 """ 

2336 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

2337 

2338 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

2339 

2340 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

2341 a = ma.masked_invalid(a) 

2342 return mstats_basic.sem(a, axis, ddof) 

2343 

2344 n = a.shape[axis] 

2345 s = np.std(a, axis=axis, ddof=ddof) / np.sqrt(n) 

2346 return s 

2347 

2348 

2349def zscore(a, axis=0, ddof=0, nan_policy='propagate'): 

2350 """ 

2351 Compute the z score. 

2352 

2353 Compute the z score of each value in the sample, relative to the 

2354 sample mean and standard deviation. 

2355 

2356 Parameters 

2357 ---------- 

2358 a : array_like 

2359 An array like object containing the sample data. 

2360 axis : int or None, optional 

2361 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 

2362 the whole array `a`. 

2363 ddof : int, optional 

2364 Degrees of freedom correction in the calculation of the 

2365 standard deviation. Default is 0. 

2366 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 

2367 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan, 

2368 'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan 

2369 values. Default is 'propagate'. 

2370 

2371 Returns 

2372 ------- 

2373 zscore : array_like 

2374 The z-scores, standardized by mean and standard deviation of 

2375 input array `a`. 

2376 

2377 Notes 

2378 ----- 

2379 This function preserves ndarray subclasses, and works also with 

2380 matrices and masked arrays (it uses `asanyarray` instead of 

2381 `asarray` for parameters). 

2382 

2383 Examples 

2384 -------- 

2385 >>> a = np.array([ 0.7972, 0.0767, 0.4383, 0.7866, 0.8091, 

2386 ... 0.1954, 0.6307, 0.6599, 0.1065, 0.0508]) 

2387 >>> from scipy import stats 

2388 >>> stats.zscore(a) 

2389 array([ 1.1273, -1.247 , -0.0552, 1.0923, 1.1664, -0.8559, 0.5786, 

2390 0.6748, -1.1488, -1.3324]) 

2391 

2392 Computing along a specified axis, using n-1 degrees of freedom 

2393 (``ddof=1``) to calculate the standard deviation: 

2394 

2395 >>> b = np.array([[ 0.3148, 0.0478, 0.6243, 0.4608], 

2396 ... [ 0.7149, 0.0775, 0.6072, 0.9656], 

2397 ... [ 0.6341, 0.1403, 0.9759, 0.4064], 

2398 ... [ 0.5918, 0.6948, 0.904 , 0.3721], 

2399 ... [ 0.0921, 0.2481, 0.1188, 0.1366]]) 

2400 >>> stats.zscore(b, axis=1, ddof=1) 

2401 array([[-0.19264823, -1.28415119, 1.07259584, 0.40420358], 

2402 [ 0.33048416, -1.37380874, 0.04251374, 1.00081084], 

2403 [ 0.26796377, -1.12598418, 1.23283094, -0.37481053], 

2404 [-0.22095197, 0.24468594, 1.19042819, -1.21416216], 

2405 [-0.82780366, 1.4457416 , -0.43867764, -0.1792603 ]]) 

2406  

2407 """ 

2408 a = np.asanyarray(a) 

2409 

2410 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy) 

2411 

2412 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit': 

2413 mns = np.nanmean(a=a, axis=axis, keepdims=True) 

2414 sstd = np.nanstd(a=a, axis=axis, ddof=ddof, keepdims=True) 

2415 else: 

2416 mns = a.mean(axis=axis, keepdims=True) 

2417 sstd = a.std(axis=axis, ddof=ddof, keepdims=True) 

2418 

2419 return (a - mns) / sstd 

2420 

2421 

2422def zmap(scores, compare, axis=0, ddof=0): 

2423 """ 

2424 Calculate the relative z-scores. 

2425 

2426 Return an array of z-scores, i.e., scores that are standardized to 

2427 zero mean and unit variance, where mean and variance are calculated 

2428 from the comparison array. 

2429 

2430 Parameters 

2431 ---------- 

2432 scores : array_like 

2433 The input for which z-scores are calculated. 

2434 compare : array_like 

2435 The input from which the mean and standard deviation of the 

2436 normalization are taken; assumed to have the same dimension as 

2437 `scores`. 

2438 axis : int or None, optional 

2439 Axis over which mean and variance of `compare` are calculated. 

2440 Default is 0. If None, compute over the whole array `scores`. 

2441 ddof : int, optional 

2442 Degrees of freedom correction in the calculation of the 

2443 standard deviation. Default is 0. 

2444 

2445 Returns 

2446 ------- 

2447 zscore : array_like 

2448 Z-scores, in the same shape as `scores`. 

2449 

2450 Notes 

2451 ----- 

2452 This function preserves ndarray subclasses, and works also with 

2453 matrices and masked arrays (it uses `asanyarray` instead of 

2454 `asarray` for parameters). 

2455 

2456 Examples 

2457 -------- 

2458 >>> from scipy.stats import zmap 

2459 >>> a = [0.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3] 

2460 >>> b = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] 

2461 >>> zmap(a, b) 

2462 array([-1.06066017, 0. , 0.35355339, 0.70710678]) 

2463  

2464 """ 

2465 scores, compare = map(np.asanyarray, [scores, compare]) 

2466 mns = compare.mean(axis=axis, keepdims=True) 

2467 sstd = compare.std(axis=axis, ddof=ddof, keepdims=True) 

2468 return (scores - mns) / sstd 

2469 

2470 

2471def gstd(a, axis=0, ddof=1): 

2472 """ 

2473 Calculate the geometric standard deviation of an array. 

2474 

2475 The geometric standard deviation describes the spread of a set of numbers 

2476 where the geometric mean is preferred. It is a multiplicative factor, and 

2477 so a dimensionless quantity. 

2478 

2479 It is defined as the exponent of the standard deviation of ``log(a)``. 

2480 Mathematically the population geometric standard deviation can be 

2481 evaluated as:: 

2482 

2483 gstd = exp(std(log(a))) 

2484 

2485 .. versionadded:: 1.3.0 

2486 

2487 Parameters 

2488 ---------- 

2489 a : array_like 

2490 An array like object containing the sample data. 

2491 axis : int, tuple or None, optional 

2492 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 

2493 the whole array `a`. 

2494 ddof : int, optional 

2495 Degree of freedom correction in the calculation of the 

2496 geometric standard deviation. Default is 1. 

2497 

2498 Returns 

2499 ------- 

2500 ndarray or float 

2501 An array of the geometric standard deviation. If `axis` is None or `a` 

2502 is a 1d array a float is returned. 

2503 

2504 Notes 

2505 ----- 

2506 As the calculation requires the use of logarithms the geometric standard 

2507 deviation only supports strictly positive values. Any non-positive or 

2508 infinite values will raise a `ValueError`. 

2509 The geometric standard deviation is sometimes confused with the exponent of 

2510 the standard deviation, ``exp(std(a))``. Instead the geometric standard 

2511 deviation is ``exp(std(log(a)))``. 

2512 The default value for `ddof` is different to the default value (0) used 

2513 by other ddof containing functions, such as ``np.std`` and ``np.nanstd``. 

2514 

2515 Examples 

2516 -------- 

2517 Find the geometric standard deviation of a log-normally distributed sample. 

2518 Note that the standard deviation of the distribution is one, on a 

2519 log scale this evaluates to approximately ``exp(1)``. 

2520 

2521 >>> from scipy.stats import gstd 

2522 >>> np.random.seed(123) 

2523 >>> sample = np.random.lognormal(mean=0, sigma=1, size=1000) 

2524 >>> gstd(sample) 

2525 2.7217860664589946 

2526 

2527 Compute the geometric standard deviation of a multidimensional array and 

2528 of a given axis. 

2529 

2530 >>> a = np.arange(1, 25).reshape(2, 3, 4) 

2531 >>> gstd(a, axis=None) 

2532 2.2944076136018947 

2533 >>> gstd(a, axis=2)
