6749 3.1374674823029505 

6750 >>> p_value 

6751 0.0057862086661515377 

6752 

6753 """ 

6754 x = np.asarray(x) 

6755 y = np.asarray(y) 

6756 

6757 # check both x and y 

6758 cnx, npx = _contains_nan(x, nan_policy) 

6759 cny, npy = _contains_nan(y, nan_policy) 

6760 contains_nan = cnx or cny 

6761 if npx == "omit" or npy == "omit": 

6762 nan_policy = "omit" 

6763 

6764 if contains_nan and nan_policy == "propagate": 

6765 return BrunnerMunzelResult(np.nan, np.nan) 

6766 elif contains_nan and nan_policy == "omit": 

6767 x = ma.masked_invalid(x) 

6768 y = ma.masked_invalid(y) 

6769 return mstats_basic.brunnermunzel(x, y, alternative, distribution) 

6770 

6771 nx = len(x) 

6772 ny = len(y) 

6773 if nx == 0 or ny == 0: 

6774 return BrunnerMunzelResult(np.nan, np.nan) 

6775 rankc = rankdata(np.concatenate((x, y))) 

6776 rankcx = rankc[0:nx] 

6777 rankcy = rankc[nx:nx+ny] 

6778 rankcx_mean = np.mean(rankcx) 

6779 rankcy_mean = np.mean(rankcy) 

6780 rankx = rankdata(x) 

6781 ranky = rankdata(y) 

6782 rankx_mean = np.mean(rankx) 

6783 ranky_mean = np.mean(ranky) 

6784 

6785 Sx = np.sum(np.power(rankcx - rankx - rankcx_mean + rankx_mean, 2.0)) 

6786 Sx /= nx - 1 

6787 Sy = np.sum(np.power(rankcy - ranky - rankcy_mean + ranky_mean, 2.0)) 

6788 Sy /= ny - 1 

6789 

6790 wbfn = nx * ny * (rankcy_mean - rankcx_mean) 

6791 wbfn /= (nx + ny) * np.sqrt(nx * Sx + ny * Sy) 

6792 

6793 if distribution == "t": 

6794 df_numer = np.power(nx * Sx + ny * Sy, 2.0) 

6795 df_denom = np.power(nx * Sx, 2.0) / (nx - 1) 

6796 df_denom += np.power(ny * Sy, 2.0) / (ny - 1) 

6797 df = df_numer / df_denom 

6798 p = distributions.t.cdf(wbfn, df) 

6799 elif distribution == "normal": 

6800 p = distributions.norm.cdf(wbfn) 

6801 else: 

6802 raise ValueError( 

6803 "distribution should be 't' or 'normal'") 

6804 

6805 if alternative == "greater": 

6806 pass 

6807 elif alternative == "less": 

6808 p = 1 - p 

6809 elif alternative == "two-sided": 

6810 p = 2 * np.min([p, 1-p]) 

6811 else: 

6812 raise ValueError( 

6813 "alternative should be 'less', 'greater' or 'two-sided'") 

6814 

6815 return BrunnerMunzelResult(wbfn, p) 

6816 

6817 

6818def combine_pvalues(pvalues, method='fisher', weights=None): 

6819 """ 

6820 Combine p-values from independent tests bearing upon the same hypothesis. 

6821 

6822 Parameters 

6823 ---------- 

6824 pvalues : array_like, 1-D 

6825 Array of p-values assumed to come from independent tests. 

6826 method : {'fisher', 'pearson', 'tippett', 'stouffer', 'mudholkar_george'}, optional 

6827 Name of method to use to combine p-values. 

6828 The following methods are available (default is 'fisher'): 

6829 

6830 * 'fisher': Fisher's method (Fisher's combined probability test), the 

6831 sum of the logarithm of the p-values 

6832 * 'pearson': Pearson's method (similar to Fisher's but uses sum of the 

6833 complement of the p-values inside the logarithms) 

6834 * 'tippett': Tippett's method (minimum of p-values) 

6835 * 'stouffer': Stouffer's Z-score method 

6836 * 'mudholkar_george': the difference of Fisher's and Pearson's methods 

6837 divided by 2 

6838 weights : array_like, 1-D, optional 

6839 Optional array of weights used only for Stouffer's Z-score method. 

6840 

6841 Returns 

6842 ------- 

6843 statistic: float 

6844 The statistic calculated by the specified method. 

6845 pval: float 

6846 The combined p-value. 

6847 

6848 Notes 

6849 ----- 

6850 Fisher's method (also known as Fisher's combined probability test) [1]_ uses 

6851 a chi-squared statistic to compute a combined p-value. The closely related 

6852 Stouffer's Z-score method [2]_ uses Z-scores rather than p-values. The 

6853 advantage of Stouffer's method is that it is straightforward to introduce 

6854 weights, which can make Stouffer's method more powerful than Fisher's 

6855 method when the p-values are from studies of different size [6]_ [7]_. 

6856 The Pearson's method uses :math:`log(1-p_i)` inside the sum whereas Fisher's 

6857 method uses :math:`log(p_i)` [4]_. For Fisher's and Pearson's method, the 

6858 sum of the logarithms is multiplied by -2 in the implementation. This 

6859 quantity has a chi-square distribution that determines the p-value. The 

6860 `mudholkar_george` method is the difference of the Fisher's and Pearson's 

6861 test statistics, each of which include the -2 factor [4]_. However, the 

6862 `mudholkar_george` method does not include these -2 factors. The test 

6863 statistic of `mudholkar_george` is the sum of logisitic random variables and 

6864 equation 3.6 in [3]_ is used to approximate the p-value based on Student's 

6865 t-distribution. 

6866 

6867 Fisher's method may be extended to combine p-values from dependent tests 

6868 [5]_. Extensions such as Brown's method and Kost's method are not currently 

6869 implemented. 

6870 

6871 .. versionadded:: 0.15.0 

6872 

6873 References 

6874 ---------- 

6875 .. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%27s_method 

6876 .. [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%27s_method#Relation_to_Stouffer.27s_Z-score_method 

6877 .. [3] George, E. O., and G. S. Mudholkar. "On the convolution of logistic 

6878 random variables." Metrika 30.1 (1983): 1-13. 

6879 .. [4] Heard, N. and Rubin-Delanchey, P. "Choosing between methods of 

6880 combining p-values." Biometrika 105.1 (2018): 239-246. 

6881 .. [5] Whitlock, M. C. "Combining probability from independent tests: the 

6882 weighted Z-method is superior to Fisher's approach." Journal of 

6883 Evolutionary Biology 18, no. 5 (2005): 1368-1373. 

6884 .. [6] Zaykin, Dmitri V. "Optimally weighted Z-test is a powerful method 

6885 for combining probabilities in meta-analysis." Journal of 

6886 Evolutionary Biology 24, no. 8 (2011): 1836-1841. 

6887 .. [7] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extensions_of_Fisher%27s_method 

6888 

6889 """ 

6890 pvalues = np.asarray(pvalues) 

6891 if pvalues.ndim != 1: 

6892 raise ValueError("pvalues is not 1-D") 

6893 

6894 if method == 'fisher': 

6895 statistic = -2 * np.sum(np.log(pvalues)) 

6896 pval = distributions.chi2.sf(statistic, 2 * len(pvalues)) 

6897 elif method == 'pearson': 

6898 statistic = -2 * np.sum(np.log1p(-pvalues)) 

6899 pval = distributions.chi2.sf(statistic, 2 * len(pvalues)) 

6900 elif method == 'mudholkar_george': 

6901 statistic = -np.sum(np.log(pvalues)) + np.sum(np.log1p(-pvalues)) 

6902 nu = 5 * len(pvalues) + 4 

6903 approx_factor = np.sqrt(nu / (nu - 2)) 

6904 pval = distributions.t.sf(statistic * approx_factor, nu) 

6905 elif method == 'tippett': 

6906 statistic = np.min(pvalues) 

6907 pval = distributions.beta.sf(statistic, 1, len(pvalues)) 

6908 elif method == 'stouffer': 

6909 if weights is None: 

6910 weights = np.ones_like(pvalues) 

6911 elif len(weights) != len(pvalues): 

6912 raise ValueError("pvalues and weights must be of the same size.") 

6913 

6914 weights = np.asarray(weights) 

6915 if weights.ndim != 1: 

6916 raise ValueError("weights is not 1-D") 

6917 

6918 Zi = distributions.norm.isf(pvalues) 

6919 statistic = np.dot(weights, Zi) / np.linalg.norm(weights) 

6920 pval = distributions.norm.sf(statistic) 

6921 

6922 else: 

6923 raise ValueError( 

6924 "Invalid method '%s'. Options are 'fisher', 'pearson', \ 

6925 'mudholkar_george', 'tippett', 'or 'stouffer'", method) 

6926 

6927 return (statistic, pval) 

6928 

6929 

6930##################################### 

6931# STATISTICAL DISTANCES # 

6932##################################### 

6933 

6934def wasserstein_distance(u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None): 

6935 r""" 

6936 Compute the first Wasserstein distance between two 1D distributions. 

6937 

6938 This distance is also known as the earth mover's distance, since it can be 

6939 seen as the minimum amount of "work" required to transform :math:`u` into 

6940 :math:`v`, where "work" is measured as the amount of distribution weight 

6941 that must be moved, multiplied by the distance it has to be moved. 

6942 

6943 .. versionadded:: 1.0.0 

6944 

6945 Parameters 

6946 ---------- 

6947 u_values, v_values : array_like 

6948 Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 

6949 u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional 

6950 Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same 

6951 weight. 

6952 `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as 

6953 `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it 

6954 must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized 

6955 to sum to 1. 

6956 

6957 Returns 

6958 ------- 

6959 distance : float 

6960 The computed distance between the distributions. 

6961 

6962 Notes 

6963 ----- 

6964 The first Wasserstein distance between the distributions :math:`u` and 

6965 :math:`v` is: 

6966 

6967 .. math:: 

6968 

6969 l_1 (u, v) = \inf_{\pi \in \Gamma (u, v)} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times 

6970 \mathbb{R}} |x-y| \mathrm{d} \pi (x, y) 

6971 

6972 where :math:`\Gamma (u, v)` is the set of (probability) distributions on 

6973 :math:`\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}` whose marginals are :math:`u` and 

6974 :math:`v` on the first and second factors respectively. 

6975 

6976 If :math:`U` and :math:`V` are the respective CDFs of :math:`u` and 

6977 :math:`v`, this distance also equals to: 

6978 

6979 .. math:: 

6980 

6981 l_1(u, v) = \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} |U-V| 

6982 

6983 See [2]_ for a proof of the equivalence of both definitions. 

6984 

6985 The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 

6986 whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 

6987 generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 

6988 functions located at the specified values. 

6989 

6990 References 

6991 ---------- 

6992 .. [1] "Wasserstein metric", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wasserstein_metric 

6993 .. [2] Ramdas, Garcia, Cuturi "On Wasserstein Two Sample Testing and Related 

6994 Families of Nonparametric Tests" (2015). :arXiv:`1509.02237`. 

6995 

6996 Examples 

6997 -------- 

6998 >>> from scipy.stats import wasserstein_distance 

6999 >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1, 3], [5, 6, 8]) 

7000 5.0 

7001 >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1], [0, 1], [3, 1], [2, 2]) 

7002 0.25 

7003 >>> wasserstein_distance([3.4, 3.9, 7.5, 7.8], [4.5, 1.4], 

7004 ... [1.4, 0.9, 3.1, 7.2], [3.2, 3.5]) 

7005 4.0781331438047861 

7006 

7007 """ 

7008 return _cdf_distance(1, u_values, v_values, u_weights, v_weights) 

7009 

7010 

7011def energy_distance(u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None): 

7012 r""" 

7013 Compute the energy distance between two 1D distributions. 

7014 

7015 .. versionadded:: 1.0.0 

7016 

7017 Parameters 

7018 ---------- 

7019 u_values, v_values : array_like 

7020 Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 

7021 u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional 

7022 Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same 

7023 weight. 

7024 `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as 

7025 `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it 

7026 must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized 

7027 to sum to 1. 

7028 

7029 Returns 

7030 ------- 

7031 distance : float 

7032 The computed distance between the distributions. 

7033 

7034 Notes 

7035 ----- 

7036 The energy distance between two distributions :math:`u` and :math:`v`, whose 

7037 respective CDFs are :math:`U` and :math:`V`, equals to: 

7038 

7039 .. math:: 

7040 

7041 D(u, v) = \left( 2\mathbb E|X - Y| - \mathbb E|X - X'| - 

7042 \mathbb E|Y - Y'| \right)^{1/2} 

7043 

7044 where :math:`X` and :math:`X'` (resp. :math:`Y` and :math:`Y'`) are 

7045 independent random variables whose probability distribution is :math:`u` 

7046 (resp. :math:`v`). 

7047 

7048 As shown in [2]_, for one-dimensional real-valued variables, the energy 

7049 distance is linked to the non-distribution-free version of the Cramer-von 

7050 Mises distance: 

7051 

7052 .. math:: 

7053 

7054 D(u, v) = \sqrt{2} l_2(u, v) = \left( 2 \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} (U-V)^2 

7055 \right)^{1/2} 

7056 

7057 Note that the common Cramer-von Mises criterion uses the distribution-free 

7058 version of the distance. See [2]_ (section 2), for more details about both 

7059 versions of the distance. 

7060 

7061 The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 

7062 whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 

7063 generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 

7064 functions located at the specified values. 

7065 

7066 References 

7067 ---------- 

7068 .. [1] "Energy distance", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_distance 

7069 .. [2] Szekely "E-statistics: The energy of statistical samples." Bowling 

7070 Green State University, Department of Mathematics and Statistics, 

7071 Technical Report 02-16 (2002). 

7072 .. [3] Rizzo, Szekely "Energy distance." Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: 

7073 Computational Statistics, 8(1):27-38 (2015). 

7074 .. [4] Bellemare, Danihelka, Dabney, Mohamed, Lakshminarayanan, Hoyer, 

7075 Munos "The Cramer Distance as a Solution to Biased Wasserstein 

7076 Gradients" (2017). :arXiv:`1705.10743`. 

7077 

7078 Examples 

7079 -------- 

7080 >>> from scipy.stats import energy_distance 

7081 >>> energy_distance([0], [2]) 

7082 2.0000000000000004 

7083 >>> energy_distance([0, 8], [0, 8], [3, 1], [2, 2]) 

7084 1.0000000000000002 

7085 >>> energy_distance([0.7, 7.4, 2.4, 6.8], [1.4, 8. ], 

7086 ... [2.1, 4.2, 7.4, 8. ], [7.6, 8.8]) 

7087 0.88003340976158217 

7088 

7089 """ 

7090 return np.sqrt(2) * _cdf_distance(2, u_values, v_values, 

7091 u_weights, v_weights) 

7092 

7093 

7094def _cdf_distance(p, u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None): 

7095 r""" 

7096 Compute, between two one-dimensional distributions :math:`u` and 

7097 :math:`v`, whose respective CDFs are :math:`U` and :math:`V`, the 

7098 statistical distance that is defined as: 

7099 

7100 .. math:: 

7101 

7102 l_p(u, v) = \left( \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} |U-V|^p \right)^{1/p} 

7103 

7104 p is a positive parameter; p = 1 gives the Wasserstein distance, p = 2 

7105 gives the energy distance. 

7106 

7107 Parameters 

7108 ---------- 

7109 u_values, v_values : array_like 

7110 Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 

7111 u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional 

7112 Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same 

7113 weight. 

7114 `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as 

7115 `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it 

7116 must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized 

7117 to sum to 1. 

7118 

7119 Returns 

7120 ------- 

7121 distance : float 

7122 The computed distance between the distributions. 

7123 

7124 Notes 

7125 ----- 

7126 The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 

7127 whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 

7128 generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 

7129 functions located at the specified values. 

7130 

7131 References 

7132 ---------- 

7133 .. [1] Bellemare, Danihelka, Dabney, Mohamed, Lakshminarayanan, Hoyer, 

7134 Munos "The Cramer Distance as a Solution to Biased Wasserstein 

7135 Gradients" (2017). :arXiv:`1705.10743`. 

7136  

7137 """ 

7138 u_values, u_weights = _validate_distribution(u_values, u_weights) 

7139 v_values, v_weights = _validate_distribution(v_values, v_weights) 

7140 

7141 u_sorter = np.argsort(u_values) 

7142 v_sorter = np.argsort(v_values) 

7143 

7144 all_values = np.concatenate((u_values, v_values)) 

7145 all_values.sort(kind='mergesort') 

7146 

7147 # Compute the differences between pairs of successive values of u and v. 

7148 deltas = np.diff(all_values) 

7149 

7150 # Get the respective positions of the values of u and v among the values of 

7151 # both distributions. 

7152 u_cdf_indices = u_values[u_sorter].searchsorted(all_values[:-1], 'right') 

7153 v_cdf_indices = v_values[v_sorter].searchsorted(all_values[:-1], 'right') 

7154 

7155 # Calculate the CDFs of u and v using their weights, if specified. 

7156 if u_weights is None: 

7157 u_cdf = u_cdf_indices / u_values.size 

7158 else: 

7159 u_sorted_cumweights = np.concatenate(([0], 

7160 np.cumsum(u_weights[u_sorter]))) 

7161 u_cdf = u_sorted_cumweights[u_cdf_indices] / u_sorted_cumweights[-1] 

7162 

7163 if v_weights is None: 

7164 v_cdf = v_cdf_indices / v_values.size 

7165 else: 

7166 v_sorted_cumweights = np.concatenate(([0], 

7167 np.cumsum(v_weights[v_sorter]))) 

7168 v_cdf = v_sorted_cumweights[v_cdf_indices] / v_sorted_cumweights[-1] 

7169 

7170 # Compute the value of the integral based on the CDFs. 

7171 # If p = 1 or p = 2, we avoid using np.power, which introduces an overhead 

7172 # of about 15%. 

7173 if p == 1: 

7174 return np.sum(np.multiply(np.abs(u_cdf - v_cdf), deltas)) 

7175 if p == 2: 

7176 return np.sqrt(np.sum(np.multiply(np.square(u_cdf - v_cdf), deltas))) 

7177 return np.power(np.sum(np.multiply(np.power(np.abs(u_cdf - v_cdf), p), 

7178 deltas)), 1/p) 

7179 

7180 

7181def _validate_distribution(values, weights): 

7182 """ 

7183 Validate the values and weights from a distribution input of `cdf_distance` 

7184 and return them as ndarray objects. 

7185 

7186 Parameters 

7187 ---------- 

7188 values : array_like 

7189 Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 

7190 weights : array_like 

7191 Weight for each value. 

7192 

7193 Returns 

7194 ------- 

7195 values : ndarray 

7196 Values as ndarray. 

7197 weights : ndarray 

7198 Weights as ndarray. 

7199  

7200 """ 

7201 # Validate the value array. 

7202 values = np.asarray(values, dtype=float) 

7203 if len(values) == 0: 

7204 raise ValueError("Distribution can't be empty.") 

7205 

7206 # Validate the weight array, if specified. 

7207 if weights is not None: 

7208 weights = np.asarray(weights, dtype=float) 

7209 if len(weights) != len(values): 

7210 raise ValueError('Value and weight array-likes for the same ' 

7211 'empirical distribution must be of the same size.') 

7212 if np.any(weights < 0): 

7213 raise ValueError('All weights must be non-negative.') 

7214 if not 0 < np.sum(weights) < np.inf: 

7215 raise ValueError('Weight array-like sum must be positive and ' 

7216 'finite. Set as None for an equal distribution of ' 

7217 'weight.') 

7218 

7219 return values, weights 

7220 

7221 return values, None 

7222 

7223 

7224##################################### 

7225# SUPPORT FUNCTIONS # 

7226##################################### 

7227 

7228RepeatedResults = namedtuple('RepeatedResults', ('values', 'counts')) 

7229 

7230 

7231def find_repeats(arr): 

7232 """ 

7233 Find repeats and repeat counts. 

7234 

7235 Parameters 

7236 ---------- 

7237 arr : array_like 

7238 Input array. This is cast to float64. 

7239 

7240 Returns 

7241 ------- 

7242 values : ndarray 

7243 The unique values from the (flattened) input that are repeated. 

7244 

7245 counts : ndarray 

7246 Number of times the corresponding 'value' is repeated. 

7247 

7248 Notes 

7249 ----- 

7250 In numpy >= 1.9 `numpy.unique` provides similar functionality. The main 

7251 difference is that `find_repeats` only returns repeated values. 

7252 

7253 Examples 

7254 -------- 

7255 >>> from scipy import stats 

7256 >>> stats.find_repeats([2, 1, 2, 3, 2, 2, 5]) 

7257 RepeatedResults(values=array([2.]), counts=array([4])) 

7258 

7259 >>> stats.find_repeats([[10, 20, 1, 2], [5, 5, 4, 4]]) 

7260 RepeatedResults(values=array([4., 5.]), counts=array([2, 2])) 

7261 

7262 """ 

7263 # Note: always copies. 

7264 return RepeatedResults(*_find_repeats(np.array(arr, dtype=np.float64))) 

7265 

7266 

7267def _sum_of_squares(a, axis=0): 

7268 """ 

7269 Square each element of the input array, and return the sum(s) of that. 

7270 

7271 Parameters 

7272 ---------- 

7273 a : array_like 

7274 Input array. 

7275 axis : int or None, optional 

7276 Axis along which to calculate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 

7277 the whole array `a`. 

7278 

7279 Returns 

7280 ------- 

7281 sum_of_squares : ndarray 

7282 The sum along the given axis for (a**2). 

7283 

7284 See Also 

7285 -------- 

7286 _square_of_sums : The square(s) of the sum(s) (the opposite of 

7287 `_sum_of_squares`). 

7288  

7289 """ 

7290 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

7291 return np.sum(a*a, axis) 

7292 

7293 

7294def _square_of_sums(a, axis=0): 

7295 """ 

7296 Sum elements of the input array, and return the square(s) of that sum. 

7297 

7298 Parameters 

7299 ---------- 

7300 a : array_like 

7301 Input array. 

7302 axis : int or None, optional 

7303 Axis along which to calculate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 

7304 the whole array `a`. 

7305 

7306 Returns 

7307 ------- 

7308 square_of_sums : float or ndarray 

7309 The square of the sum over `axis`. 

7310 

7311 See Also 

7312 -------- 

7313 _sum_of_squares : The sum of squares (the opposite of `square_of_sums`). 

7314  

7315 """ 

7316 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis) 

7317 s = np.sum(a, axis) 

7318 if not np.isscalar(s): 

7319 return s.astype(float) * s 

7320 else: 

7321 return float(s) * s 

7322 

7323 

7324def rankdata(a, method='average'): 

7325 """ 

7326 Assign ranks to data, dealing with ties appropriately. 

7327 

7328 Ranks begin at 1. The `method` argument controls how ranks are assigned 

7329 to equal values. See [1]_ for further discussion of ranking methods. 

7330 

7331 Parameters 

7332 ---------- 

7333 a : array_like 

7334 The array of values to be ranked. The array is first flattened. 

7335 method : {'average', 'min', 'max', 'dense', 'ordinal'}, optional 

7336 The method used to assign ranks to tied elements. 

7337 The following methods are available (default is 'average'): 

7338 

7339 * 'average': The average of the ranks that would have been assigned to 

7340 all the tied values is assigned to each value. 

7341 * 'min': The minimum of the ranks that would have been assigned to all 

7342 the tied values is assigned to each value. (This is also 

7343 referred to as "competition" ranking.) 

7344 * 'max': The maximum of the ranks that would have been assigned to all 

7345 the tied values is assigned to each value. 

7346 * 'dense': Like 'min', but the rank of the next highest element is 

7347 assigned the rank immediately after those assigned to the tied 

7348 elements. 

7349 * 'ordinal': All values are given a distinct rank, corresponding to 

7350 the order that the values occur in `a`. 

7351 

7352 Returns 

7353 ------- 

7354 ranks : ndarray 

7355 An array of length equal to the size of `a`, containing rank 

7356 scores. 

7357 

7358 References 

7359 ---------- 

7360 .. [1] "Ranking", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranking 

7361 

7362 Examples 

7363 -------- 

7364 >>> from scipy.stats import rankdata 

7365 >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2]) 

7366 array([ 1. , 2.5, 4. , 2.5]) 

7367 >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='min') 

7368 array([ 1, 2, 4, 2]) 

7369 >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='max') 

7370 array([ 1, 3, 4, 3]) 

7371 >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='dense') 

7372 array([ 1, 2, 3, 2]) 

7373 >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='ordinal') 

7374 array([ 1, 2, 4, 3]) 

7375  

7376 """ 

7377 if method not in ('average', 'min', 'max', 'dense', 'ordinal'): 

7378 raise ValueError('unknown method "{0}"'.format(method)) 

7379 

7380 arr = np.ravel(np.asarray(a)) 

7381 algo = 'mergesort' if method == 'ordinal' else 'quicksort' 

7382 sorter = np.argsort(arr, kind=algo) 

7383 

7384 inv = np.empty(sorter.size, dtype=np.intp) 

7385 inv[sorter] = np.arange(sorter.size, dtype=np.intp) 

7386 

7387 if method == 'ordinal': 

7388 return inv + 1 

7389 

7390 arr = arr[sorter] 

7391 obs = np.r_[True, arr[1:] != arr[:-1]] 

7392 dense = obs.cumsum()[inv] 

7393 

7394 if method == 'dense': 

7395 return dense 

7396 

7397 # cumulative counts of each unique value 

7398 count = np.r_[np.nonzero(obs)[0], len(obs)] 

7399 

7400 if method == 'max': 

7401 return count[dense] 

7402 

7403 if method == 'min': 

7404 return count[dense - 1] + 1 

7405 

7406 # average method 

7407 return .5 * (count[dense] + count[dense - 1] + 1) 

« index     coverage.py v5.1, created at 2020-05-31 14:32
